title: blind mans sight restored 30 years world first gene editing
story: A blind man who lost his sight nearly 40 years ago can see objects again after his eye cells were genetically modified to become sensitive to light. The 58-year-old had suffered from retinitis pigmentosa (RP), a condition in which the top layer of the retina degenerates so the eye can no longer sense light, for most of his adult life.Nearly 13 years ago, scientists theorised that intact ganglion cells at the bottom of the retina could be repurposed to become light-sensitive cells and take on the role of the damaged top layer.In a groundbreaking experiment, they genetically modified one eye by inserting genes from light-sensitive algae into the ganglion cells and triggered them using special goggles.The goggles record the world in real time and convert the image into pulses of red and amber light which shine into the retina, activating the cells, which connect to the optic nerve and restore sight.The treatment allowed the patient to recognise, count, locate and touch objects for the first time in decades. Prof Botond Roska, of the University of Basel in Switzerland, said: The retina is a biological computer at the back of your eye. It's like hamburger – the top bread is a photosensitive layer and the bottom bread forms the optic nerve and talks to the rest of our brain. In between, representing the salad, the tomato and meat, is the computational layers that computes the visual field.“In retinitis pigmentosa, the photosensitive layer is damaged but the rest is intact, like a hamburger without the top bread. In optogenetic therapy we create an artificial photosensitive layer targeting ganglion cells which are the lower bread. The brain has to learn a new language because the signals coming from the ganglion cells are not the usual signals.Retinitis pigmentosa affects one in 4,000 people in Britain – about 16,500 –and there is currently no treatment except for a gene replacement therapy that works only on an early-onset form of the disease to prevent further damage.The scientists believe the man's eyesight will continue to improve with more training. Treatment had to stop last year because of coronavirus, and several other patients are also currently undergoing the therapy.Prof José-Alain Sahel, of Sorbonne University in Paris, said: Before the treatment the patient couldn't see anything, but spontaneously he was able to see stripes on the street, and then was able to detect objects on the table and to grasp the objects and count the objects.We knew it was a very promising field, and obviously when you've worked on something for so long and you have the first patient telling you they are seeing something, it's very exciting. It's a major milestone. The researchers believe blind patients will be keen to have the treatment because the gene insertion technique is simple, and the goggles are not intrusive.Prof Sahel added: I am convinced patients are going to use it because it's a very little invasive surgery, it's well tolerated so far. The new goggles are quite thin so everyone won't be looking at you in the street.It is a stepping stone. In the next five to 10 years, this will improve significantly. So I think it is like cars – you look back at last century cars and they are very different from the current BMWs.British scientists hailed the work but said more studies would be needed to find out if it could restore sight to a useful level for many people.James Bainbridge, professor of retinal sudies at University College London, said: This exciting new technology might help people whose eyesight is very severely impaired.It is a high-quality study. It is carefully conducted and controlled. The findings are based on laboratory tests in just one inidual. Further work will be needed to find out if the technology can be expected to provide useful vision. The intervention appeared to improve the ability to locate an object by sight.The research was published in the journal Nature Medicine.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: many syrians can dream future certain election result
story: With less than a week to go before Syria's presidential election, Emad was giving little thought to politics or how to cast his vote.Instead, the engineering graduate was plotting an escape from spiralling rents, unemployment, and  shortages of fuel and food that he described as unbearable. I have little money to travel, but I have to leave, there’s nothing here for me anymore, he said in his flat in Western Damascus.  It’s becoming worse and worse, the bad economy, the falling currency, the growing corruption, the hard sanctions and only a small number of people are happy here, the country is only for the rich.”Syrians go to the polls on Wednesday to vote in a presidential election that the authorities here would like to present as a return to normality after a decade of devastating warfare.There is little doubt about the outcome of the election. Fifty-one candidates have been whittled down to three, and incumbent Bashar al-Assad shows no willingness to relinquish his grip on power after 21 years.But the dislocation of the war, foreign sanctions and a crisis in neighbouring Lebanon has sent the economy into meltdown.And a new wave of middle-class Syrians is hoping to flee  - despite the efforts of Assad's government to lure them back, and European countries to deter them.When I have sold what possessions I own, and my mother sells her jewellery, we will have to pay smugglers in Damascus, who will take me to Turkey and then on to Europe, said Emad.“It costs a minimum of $10,000 dollars, who has this amount? he says. But the choice is stay here and lose time in a terrible situation or try and borrow or find a solution and improve the situation, the basic components of a good life don’t exist in Syria any more for me, my family is now relying on me to provide for them in the future.”The conflict that broke out here in 2011 has killed more than 388,000 people and prompted more than half of Syria's pre-war population to flee their homes.  A record 12.4 million people, approximately 65 per cent of the Syrian population, are now food insecure. That figure has grown by 4.5 million in the space of a year.  But getting out is not easy.After the turmoil of the 2015 migrant crisis, in which 378,000 Syrians sought refuge in Europe, attitudes on the continent have hardened.Denmark earlier this year declared that Syria was a safe place for refugees to return to, despite ongoing repression and the risk of retribution many people say they will face if they return.In November last year, the Syrian authorities hosted an extravagant conference in Damascus seeking to lure back the more than six million refugees who left the country over the past ten years.Few seem willing to heed that call.Recent studies show that 90 percent of Syrian refugees in Lebanon, Jordan, Iraq, and Egypt do not intend to return to Syria within the next year, even if they are unable to meet their basic needs in their host countries.In Damascus, the line between normality and chaos is often as narrow as a single road separating neighbourhoods.Some streets are so clean and tidy they could be in Switzerland, while nearby suburbs have been reduced to rows of destroyed buildings.The extreme contrast between the very wealthy - many of whom are acolytes of the Assad regime - and regular middle-class people is on display in every aspect of daily life.“Sometimes you can see the latest cars in the street, BMW’s and Range Rovers from 2021, with Syrian number plates. Most people would have to work 1000 years to buy them. The rest of the country struggles to eat meat and find basic services, hunger is everywhere,” said Doha Barakat, a student at Damascus University.For ordinary people, just finding the fuel to drive a car is a challenge. Queues for petrol fill streets as people wait for a weekly text message from a government-run services provider giving them a ration of just 25 litres of subsidised petrol.“I can’t bear it anymore, waiting hours on end for scarce petrol and I can’t even afford it, so to cut costs I have to walk,” said  Zakaraya Aboud, a 27-year-old trainee lawyer who now trudges 30 minutes in searing heat to get to work each day.“I’m going to try and move to Germany or France, by any means, even if it means I will be a refugee then so be it, I will have to sell my car to do it,” he added.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: milky way formed peacefully not collision another galaxy scientists
story: The Milky Way formed billions of years ago as the result of a peaceful and natural process, a new study claims. It was thought that the Milky Way's thin and thick discs formed after a rare violent merger, and so probably wouldn't be found in other spiral galaxies.“Our research shows that's probably wrong, and it evolved naturally without catastrophic interventions. This means Milky Way-type galaxies are probably very common.Researchers used the European Southern Observatory's Very Large Telescope (VLT) in Chile to study the composition of the stars located within discs of UGC 10738. A highly sophisticated spectroscopy tool called MUSE was able to determine the ratio of metals, such as iron, to other elements, like helium, in these stars. Analysis found their signatures to be largely similar to that of those seen in the Milky Way.“We're looking at some other galaxies to make sure, but that's pretty strong evidence that the two galaxies evolved in the same way,” said Dr Jesse van de Sande, also from ASTRO 3D.“This is an interesting study and it definitely helps answer some questions about how the structures we see in the Milky Way might have formed,” he said. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: pandemic response has massive costs ignored
story: The pandemic response has had massive other costs which are being ignored, ethics advisers to the Government have warned.Experts from the UK Pandemic Ethics Accelerator collaborative, which has previously advised the Government on making vaccinations mandatory for care workers, said decisions had focussed on reducing mortality at the expense of equality and liberty.They argue that it is important to balance the cost of tackling Covid-19 against the harms to education, mental health, freedom and other health conditions.Prof John Coggon, professor of Law, Centre for Health, Law, and Society at the University of Bristol: “None of us is insensitive to the great harm that Covid-19 has caused, including families who lost loved ones and friends. “The bottom line here is that the amount of harm that has eventuated in other regards also needs to be brought into that discussion.“Protecting health has been a clear and ethical goal. But, health is more than one thing, and something that helped in one way may harm it in another.”The experts said the Government had focussed too heavily on mortality statistics without addressing the other problems associated with lockdown and restricting NHS services.Dominic Wilkinson, professor of medical ethics at the Oxford Uehiro Centre for Practical Ethics added: “One of the real dangers of a pandemic response is by directing our attention solely to one particular variable, we forsake these other costs and I think there's been massive other health costs of the pandemic response. “Now that might be justified. But we have to be clear that those costs exist, and, and we have to be transparent about that when we're making very difficult choices. We should remember that deaths and illnesses from other causes are also at stake.”Dr Sarah Chan, deputy director, Mason Institute for Medicine, Life Sciences and Law, University of Edinburgh, said the Government had tended to focus on measuring deaths because it was harder to quantify the impact on freedom or equality.“Measuring numerical values, especially when it comes to Covid-19 deaths has skewed attention away from the ethical values that should underpin our decisions,” she said.Newly released figures have also revealed that the Indian variant of Covid-19 now accounts for more than a third of cases in England, a five-fold rise in the strain's prevalence in just a fortnight.Random sampling of positive Covid-19 tests in the community analysed by Wellcome Sanger show that 37 per cent of cases were identified as B.1.617.2 (the technical name of the variant first identified in Indian) in the two weeks to May 15. That is compared to seven per cent in the two weeks to May 1, a significant spike in prevalence that suggests the Indian variant could soon become the dominant strain in England. More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: parliament must not settling old scores
story: Rarely has a former government official generated such a damaging political brouhaha as that being stirred up by Dominic Cummings. In a series of comments ahead of his appearance before a joint select committee hearing on Wednesday the Prime Minister’s former chief adviser has sought to create a narrative around Covid policy that portrays everyone but himself as incompetent.The self-indulgence of this exercise is stupefying. It seems designed to cause maximum damage to Boris Johnson for reasons that are personal rather than to illuminate the strategic mistakes of his government. Moreover, Mr Cummings fails to acknowledge that he was responsible for government communications throughout the pandemic. If there were confusing messages he was as responsible as anyone. He was a participant not an onlooker.Mr Cummings has been invited to give evidence to two select committees about the UK’s preparedness for the pandemic that hit last year. A parliamentary committee should not be used as a vehicle for vengeful retribution by a former official. As Jeremy Hunt, the former Cabinet minister and chairman of the health committee, said the proceedings must not be dominated by “political dirty washing or score-settling”. Yet friends of Mr Cummings have spoken of his desire to “napalm” his former boss in No 10 even to the extent of disclosing sensitive papers that he has retained since leaving his post.MPs are entitled to see information relevant to understanding how decisions were made when the scale of the virus became apparent. They are also justified in asking how pandemic planning had been updated and whether it was properly deployed. They might also usefully ask what analysis he and others inside Downing Street carried out of the likely consequences of locking down the country for months on end.In one of his numerous tweets Mr Cummings recently said that “many thousands will have serious health problems for years because of our failure to act fasterharder in FebMarch &amp Sep.” Was any calculation made of the long-term health impacts of the lockdowns themselves with some 300,000 missed cancer diagnoses feared?If Mr Cummings’s contribution is designed to ensure that we are better prepared in future to deal with a pandemic then it is to be welcomed. If it is the latest chapter in a lengthy vendetta motivated by personal grievance it needs to be seen in that context.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: rhodes saved no end sight woke crusade
story: There seems to be no end to the discovery of new targets for the “Woke-Folk” with Darwin now being denounced for racism, sexism and misogyny. Rhodes has long been beyond the pale with calls for the removal of his statue from Oriel College, Oxford. The authorities now say that it would be too expensive to pull down, evoking fury from the Rhodes Must Fall Campaign, which describes the decision as “a slap in the face with the hand of white supremacy.” One might have thought the members of the campaign who think this all so important might have offered to raise the money themselves, but they keep their wallets firmly closed.What is more, they seem to have no compunction about taking advantage of the facilities endowed by Rhodes from his trading activities which they deplore. Rhodes has long been a target of the “Woke-Folk” but Professor Fuentes of Princeton University condemns Darwin of letting his scientific process becoming warped by his prejudices and accuses him of using his theories to condone colonialism, imperialism and genocide. As I read Darwin, he merely noted that different tribes of mankind in different parts of the world had reached different levels of scientific knowledge and economic progress. I am a bit more relaxed about much of this than Professor Fuentes.I notice the ascendancy of athletes of colour in many sports with complete equanimity, just as I do that in many others including my favourite sport of cricket. Men have an advantage over women from the greater size and weight. None of that lessens my enjoyment of watching women’s cricket. I also enjoy watching equestrian events and here the skills of men and women and the capacity of mares and stallions with a woman jockey riding a mare to win the recent Grand National.    I have long argued that whatever the merits or demerits of our primary and secondary education system we lack a technical education system to provide the skills needed in the employment market.Some years ago we had such a system, although nothing to match that in Germany, but counter-productive education reforms obliterated it in favour of third rate universities which beguiled school leavers into taking out loans to finance themselves to acquire commercially valueless degrees in subjects such as “media studies”. The commercially valuable skills and crafts such as data processing, high grade construction industry skills such as carpentry, joinery, brick-laying, scaffolding and the like were all regarded as below the threshold of the newly dignified tertiary education system. So I have high hopes of the Government’s Skills and Post-16 Education Bill which the Secretary of State sent into the House of Lords last week, expressing the Government’s wish “ to address the severe shortage of qualified people in key sectors such as engineering and health and social care.” And I particularly liked his commitment to “support the provision of high quality, higher level technical qualifications that can provide a valuable alternative to a university degree”.I am much less encouraged by an apparent failure of the Transport Department to understand the prime reason for the poor performance of the railway system. If only the Secretary of State and his advisers would look back to the years before the 1945 Labour Government took the railways into state ownership, he would see that each of the four great railway companies owned not only the rolling stock but the tracks, signalling systems and stations required to provide passenger and freight facilities. During the Second World War there was an understandable lack of investment in the railways and that was worsened after they were taken into state ownership. The Treasury was under great pressure to improve the National Health Service, pensions and the like and the needs of the railways were pushed aside in favour of investment in the more politically “sexy” areas.Now, whether the railway system remains in state ownership or is liberated into the private sector, in each of the isions, (the former great companies), Southern, London North Eastern, London Midland and Scottish, and The Great Western, the tracks, signalling systems, passenger facilities and rolling stock must be managed and owned as a single unit. If they are not, there would be unceasing conflict between the train operators wanting better signalling and passenger facilities and the companies owning those things wishing to minimize their capital investment and maximise their rental charges. One other of our great British institutions, the BBC, looks to be in some problems for having connived in the appalling conduct and deceits around the interview given by Princess Dianna to Martin Bashir. Although it was not related to political partisanship it can only add to disquiet about the management of the BBC which has too often taken sides in such controversies. Great institutions such as the BBC are all too likely to do more to serve themselves and their staff unless they enjoy a strong management with a company of openness. Change is overdue.Finally, as I look back at my praise of N.A.S.A. for the first landing of an explorer on Mars, it would be churlish not to mark the similar remarkable Chinese achievement which leaves us Europeans standing.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: snp may play cynical politics immigration enforcement plenty
story: The home secretary couldn’t have got a better reaction even if she had been deliberately trolling her Scottish opponents.A fortnight ago an attempt by immigration authorities to remove two men who were living illegally in Glasgow was foiled after local residents blockaded the van carrying them. After an hours-long stand-off, the police advised that the two men should be released. This was welcomed by campaigners for open borders as a great triumph of people power and a rebuke to the rule of the UK government in Scotland.Following a speech on immigration today, Priti Patel insisted she would authorise such an operation again and that that is what the “British people voted for”.You could almost hear the indignant spluttering of keyboard warriors across the country as the home secretary was taken to task on her audacity. Perhaps the British people did indeed vote for such a heartless system, but the Scottish people (being genetically predisposed to fairness and niceness, of course) certainly did not, was the general tenor of the response.At the risk of ruining everyone’s day with inconvenient stuff like facts, allow me to make a few salient points that just about every politician in Scotland – including, to its shame, the Scottish Labour Party – have forgotten.First, it is entirely accurate to suggest that the people of Britain have indeed voted consistently for governments that have taken a robust approach to those who arrive here with a visa and then decide to remain here after it has expired. Such people did not arrive here seeking asylum, they are not refugees. They signed documents committing them to respecting the terms of their visas, they understood the consequences of disobeying the law. They accepted the terms. For those who deliberately and illegally overstay their welcome, uniformed men banging on their door at unexpected hours is not the first indication they have had that they may be flouting UK law. They are contacted on a number of occasions by immigration officials and it is explained to them, repeatedly, what the consequences will be if they ignore an instruction to leave of their own volition.If we have got to a stage when they have to be forcibly removed it is because they have deliberately ignored numerous polite requests that they comply with the arrangement they themselves voluntarily entered into before they got here.Secondly, voters across the UK – including many in Scotland – have consistently voted for governments, whether Labour or Conservative, who have been committed to the rule of law in immigration as in areas of more general criminality. Even those who now vote SNP are supporting a party that, in its 2013 white paper on independence, insisted that only those immigrants who fulfil certain criteria would be allowed to remain here.And here is a truth that is rarely uttered but needs to be acknowledged more frequently: by voting No to independence in 2014, the Scottish people acknowledged that they would be subject to the law, as legislated for at Westminster, on all matters reserved to the UK government. That included immigration, and everyone in Scotland, including all its political parties, understood that to be the case. A vote to remain in the UK was a vote for the devolution settlement, a settlement that ensured that immigration and a range of other vital issues would be the responsibility of the whole of the UK and not just Scotland.Opportunistic, populist political leaders who have signed a letter opposing immigration raids know this to be the case. The Scottish Labour ones in particular who added their signatures are playing a desperately dangerous game by supporting a nationalist agenda that seeks to depict Scotland as an unwilling, victimised part of the UK that didn’t really know what it was voting for when it rejected independence seven years ago.But we did know. Not only that but it is simply wishful thinking to state that “Scotland” is a single homogenous political entity and that it opposes immigration raids. There are plenty of people in Scotland who are realistic and grown up enough to recognise that if any country is to have an immigration policy (and all democratic countries do), then it should be enforced. The SNP can afford to grandstand cynically on this issue because they don’t have any powers over immigration (thanks to that vote by the Scottish people in 2014) and, in the event of independence, would have no compunction about sending in the immigration enforcers, since their only political ambition would by then have been achieved.Scottish Labour, similarly, has no prospect of holding immigration powers in Edinburgh, even if it ever wins power there. But by banging the nationalists’ drum on immigration, the party is undermining the devolution settlement when they should be supporting it. If its leader, Anas Sarwar, believes a Labour government at UK level will take a different approach, he should campaign for that. But claiming that immigration law and enforcement should not be happening in any part of the country where the UK government’s writ – as authorised by the Scottish people – runs, is doing the separatists’ job for them.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: stonewall finally paying price turning back gay men lesbians
story: This weekend, the reputation of LGBT charity Stonewall crashed as decisively as the British Eurovision entry. Not only did Matthew Parris, one of Stonewall’s founders, criticise their foray ‘into the trans rights war’ but they lost a key relationship with the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC).This is not a minor blip in the culture wars it is the beginning of a reckoning against the woke authoritarianism that has gripped British institutions. For the past 20 years Stonewall has invited organisations to join its Diversity Champions scheme, whereby members pay a fee and allow the charity to vet their internal policies. The 850 signed-up include the Ministry of Justice and Cabinet Office.But this weekend it was revealed the EHRC will not be renewing their membership a blow for Stonewall which trades on its image as the equality expert. A letter from EHRC chairwoman Baroness Falkner stated membership of the scheme “had no influence on external work” and that the decision not to renew membership was purely financial. But the news follows increasing public disquiet about the role of Stonewall in shaping policies which critics argue undermine existing sex-based rights and penalise those who refuse to accept that ‘transwomen are women.’Last week saw the publication of the Reindorf Report, an independent investigation into the no-platforming of feminist academics by the University of Essex. Professors Phoenix and Freedman were disinvited from speaking due to preconceptions about their views on transgender people. Along with 120 other universities, University of Essex is a Stonewall Diversity Champion.The report was damning, noting the university had adopted policies which reflected “the law as Stonewall would prefer it to be, rather than the law as it is.” Significantly, it advised that should the university continue with its membership of the Stonewall scheme it “devise a strategy for countering the drawbacks and potential illegalities.” Stonewall’s problems can be traced to the appointment of Ruth Hunt in 2014.Having won the fight for same sex marriage, there was nowhere to progress for lesbian, gay and bisexual equality. Following a consultation with 700 trans people, in 2015 Stonewall accepted a donation to ‘integrate trans-specific work’ into its campaigns. In 2019 Hunt left Stonewall and accepted a peerage.There is no link between people who identify as trans and those who are same-sex attracted the addition of the ‘T’ to the ‘LGB’ was more about funding than facts. Today Stonewall promotes the notion that each of us has a ‘gender identity’ and that this might not align with our sexed bodies. By doing so Stonewall opened the ideological door to the concept of ‘lesbians with penises’ and ‘gay men with vulvas.’ Unsurprisingly, many lesbians and gay men have objected to this idea.Simon Fanshawe OBE was one of Stonewall’s founders he believes the charity has strayed from its core purpose and that it is now “entirely devoted to political conformity.” “Stonewall is no longer an advisor and campaigner on lesbian and gay equality. Instead, it has set itself up as the arbiter of who is the right kind of gay. It’s tells any gay man or lesbian who does not agree with its gender ideology that they have put themselves 'outside Stonewall'.”Fanshawe is far from alone in his criticism of Stonewall. Allison Bailey is a lesbian barrister with concerns about the embedding of gender ideology in institutions. Bailey alleges that Stonewall colluded with her employer to remove her and is suing both.On Monday 24 May, in an attempt to deflect from negative coverage Stonewall launched a new strategy with the strapline ‘Free to be.’ But there is no freedom for gay men like Simon Fanshawe or lesbians like Allison Bailey to be critical of gender ideology. Having undermined its foundations by alienating same-sex attracted people, it seems Stonewall may finally be about to fall.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: submarine telegram 1851 thought worlds first goes hammer
story: The message was transmitted across 25 nautical miles of copper wire carried across the English Channel from South Foreland, in Kent, to Calais.It reads: PRINTED-FROM-ENGLAND-TO-FRANCE-SEPT-28-1851-6-P-M. The piece of paper, complete with a scrapbook of information and cuttings about the breakthrough moment, is being sold by a private collector and is expected to fetch up to £5,000 on Tuesday. It is a tiny slip of paper, and the only way it survived is because the original recipient placed it into an album.This telegram sits right at the beginning of communication between nations and across the sea, signalling a really important moment.They founded the Submarine  Company with the goal of taking the technology international. Using their familial wealth, they mounted an experimental attempt to connect Calais and Dover on August 28, 1850, and it was a partial success.The flimsy cable laid across the seabed soon broke, but not before it had enabled a message to be sent from England to France.The messages were severely distorted and only a garbled, indecipherable jumble of characters was transmitted, but the proof of concept was enough to garner worldwide attention and allow the brothers to secure further funding.This allowed a more robust cable to be built which would not only survive for longer, but would maintain the integrity of the original message.The next expedition, on September 25, featured this iron-clad copper cable, which was able to protect against saltwater and rogue fishing ships, which had both scuppered previous attempts. However, the brothers had underestimated how much cable was needed to be able to cross the channel and their 25 nautical miles of insulated copper left them more than a mile adrift off the French coast. The cable was laid across the sea bed, which makes it not so strange that they ran out of cable as there are unknown metrics and undulations to contend with, Dr Heaton told The . The technology was so experimental that they went out to sea and realised they were a couple of miles short and ran out of cable. They had this fairly good quality cable within two miles of Calais and then they had to jerry rig the last stretch to the shore with a substandard substitute.The telegram up for auction was sent two days after the cable was completed along this spliced line, and before the final stretch was upgraded about a month later.An official opening of the international submarine telegram network was held on November 19, 1851, when the line was open for public use. The blueprint created by the Submarine  Company's submarine system was used to create the transatlantic version which sent its first messages in 1858.The item is being sold as part of a collection at Sotheby's auction house, starting on Tuesday at 2pm.Other lots available include a signed letter from Albert Einstein to his son, a signed letter from Charles Darwin to the prominent 19th century zoologist Enrico Giglioli and an autograph by the late Stephen Hawking, dated to 1979.The day of science-oriented items also includes work relating to Alexander von Humbolt, Johannes Kepler, Nicolaus Copernicus, Louis Pasteur and Mary Anning.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

Andyou read my letter to Lord Deighton youaposll see we were frustrated and fearful for the fact that we could not deploy our sales force, our warehousing resource, our quality assurance and our technical expertise theand breadth of the UK. He added: I believe [The Department of Health and Social Care] were dealing with an exponential rise in offers without any filtering in place to decide what was a bona fide offer and what was a speculative offer. Meanwhile, Sarah Stoute, CEO of major PPE supplier Full Support Healthcare , said she had warned the government they faced imminent supply issues as early as December . “We started to talk to them about stock issues in December ,” She said.  “All of the hubs in the country were emptying. There was no stock and hospitals had started to call, to say they were in a panic. It took all of December and January to beg [the Government] to release the Brexit stock as a matter of emergency, whilst we went to production full-scale in the background, and urged them to place orders on products that were running out.“There were three suppliers providing a particular product, all three based in Wuhan, and I made a call to say: ‘You’re going to have a major problem on this, because nothing is coming out of Wuhan. You need to ring the other two suppliers and buy everything you can get your hands on. You’re going to need a huge amount, it doesn’t matter where it comes from, just get the product’. The person I was speaking to in inventory tried to escalate that and was ignored – and was in a very stressed state about it.” Ms Stoute said her firm risked financial ruin by ramping up production massively while the Government were still trying to understand the scale of the crisis.  She added: We’d already gone to production for things we couldn’t afford to pay for, waiting for the Government to catch-up.” Ms Stoute said the Government gives her firm a forecast of what PPE they will need for the winter every year, which they ignore, because it’s always less than the year before - and roughly half what the NHS needs. She added: “Every single winter there is a shortage that is covered up by the fact that we over order.”FOLLOW USMirrorPoliticsFollow @MirrorPoliticsCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnNHSHospitalsCoronavirus

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeRobyn Sexton sat at her computer with her husband Ward by her side. Then she typed out the email she hoped she’d never have to write. We need a kidney. More accurately, Gavin needs a kidney, and we hope this letter helps explain why we are asking so much of you. Gavin, Robyn and Ward’s eight-year-old son, had had a dficult start to le. After being diagnosed with stage  Wilm’s Tumour, a form of kidney cancer found in children, when he was just three, Gavin had spent much of his short le in treatment. “He had an operation to remove the tumour along with his left kidney. Then he had chemotherapy and radiotherapy,” Robyn told The Mirror. After a few cycles of treatment, scans revealed the cancer had spread to Gavin’s lungs - and that meant yet more treatment.  The Sextons breathed a sigh of relief when Gavin finished chemo and radiotherapy and was in remission. But their joy was short lived as the cancer ed a year later. “They discovered it near the kidney again. Doctors told us he’d need tough radiotherapy which would eventually destroy Gavin’s remaining kidney,” Robyn said. Another few months of gruelling treatment followed before Gavin was declared cancer-free again. Three months later, he went into renal failure when his kidney stopped working. “We knew it was coming but we had no idea it would be that quick,” Robyn added.  Now eight-and-a-half years old, Gavin was put on dialysis. He missed out on so much. He couldn’t play sports with his friends. We’d signed him up for swimming lessons, but you’re not allowed to swim on dialysis.” Robyn and Ward knew their youngest son’s lestyle couldn’t go on forever - he needed a transplant. But Gavin had to be two years cancer-free before he was eligible for a new kidney. For the next few years, the routine remained the same. Every night before he went to bed, little Gavin was hooked up to a dialysis machine that cleaned his blood for  hours. Finally, Gavin passed the milestone of two years without cancer and his parents put him straight on the deceased donor list.  “The problem is, sometimes the wait for a new organ can take years,” Robyn explained. Gavin had already been through so much.Both Robyn and Ward were tested to seethey could give Gavin one of their kidneys. Robyn wasn’t a match. Gavin was eligible, but he had high blood pressure so the procedure would be riskier.Now they took matters into their own hands. They typed out an email to their friends and family, hoping someone would be kind enough to get tested. After a few weeks, Robyn received a message from Ann Chiumino. She didn’t know the family, but she’d been forwarded the email. She also happened to be an administrator at Gavin’s school and she wanted to give him her kidney.  “I met up with Ann and she said she was touched by our story. She told me that donating her kidney to Gavin was something she felt she had to do. “I just thought, ‘wow, this is so kind that she wants to put herself in this process’,” Robyn said. Ann explained she had discussed her plans with her husband and two daughters, and they were happy for her to go ahead.Soon after Ann threw her hat in the ring, the coronavirus pandemic hit, putting Gavin’s operation on hold. But despite the long wait, Ann never wavered in her commitment to the family. When lockdown lted, she began having tests to confirm she was a match and healthy enough to donate her kidney. Finally, in February , the day of the operation came around. An anxious Robyn and Ward went into hospital with Gavin and had a nail-biting nine hour wait while he and Ann went under. “We were getting live updates like: ‘The kidney’s on ice’ - it was exciting but weird,” Robyn recalled. Thankfully the operation was a success and after three long years, Gavin, now , finally had a new kidney.  “There were still coronavirus restrictions in place but Ward and I were allowed to be with Gavin when he woke up. “Then the next day, I was lucky enough to be allowed to see Ann too.” As Robyn saw the woman who had saved her son’s le, she was almost lost for words. “All I could do was tell her she was an angel. I was awestruck by her selflessness,” she said. Ann was groggy and in a bit of pain, but she’d done amazingly well and was allowed home to recover the next day. After two and a half weeks in hospital while Ward and Robyn taking turns to stay the night, Gavin came home too.  “We invited Ann and her family over a few days later to see Gavin for a little meet-and-greet. It was lovely to see them together. “They’ve seen each other a few times since and they’re building a really sweet relationship. I know they’ll be lelong friends.” After a dficult few weeks of managing new medicine and pain, Gavin is getting better every day. His appetite, which had been suppressed by dialysis, is coming back and he’s enjoying his favourite treats of biscuits and chocolate milk. His older brothers, Ben, , and Ryan, , are relieved to have him home too. “They’re all incredibly close - they still fight though!” Robyn said. With a new kidney in tow, Gavin will soon be allowed to do so many of the things he missed out on - like school trips, non-contact sports and sleepovers with his friends. “He’s such a fun, energetic, sweet boy who loves his friends,” Robyn said. “And Ann is a member of our family now. I still can’t believe how selfless she is. If our story can inspire even one person to become an organ donor, then it’s worth telling.”FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnOrgan donation

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeAs Hannah Grady looked at the two blue lines on her pregnancy test, she felt overwhelmed. Although she was happy to be carrying her fourth child, she’d recently suffered a miscarriage. “It was really scary. I was bleeding for the first  weeks of the pregnancy, which is the same thing that happened when I lost my previous pregnancy,” Hannah, now , told The Mirror. Luckily, scans revealed Hannah’s unborn child was doing well. Then, at  weeks pregnant, the mum-of-four went into preterm labour. She was admitted hospital and given injections to pause labour, which worked. That’s when things started to go downhill. “I started having dizziness, which doctors put down to anaemia. Then my balance became affected and I was told it was an ear infection,” Hannah recalled. Hannah accepted the diagnosis, but there was a niggling thought in her mind.  “When I was three years old I had a brain tumour. I can’t remember it but I know I had my third birthday in hospital. Once I’d finished treatment I grew up like a normal child. “The thought of having another brain tumour briefly crossed my mind but I knew they were rare so I thought it couldn’t be that,” she said.But as the weeks passed, Hannah’s symptoms got worse. Soon, she was suffering from searing headaches as well as balance issues.“By now I knew it was worse than an ear infection. The pressure in my head was unbearable,” she explained.  After being induced, Hannah battled through a gruelling labour with her partner Jordan by her side before giving birth to her daughter Pippa. “I felt so ill. As I was pushing Pippa out, the pressure in my head got worse. I don’t know how I did it because I was so weak,” she described. By now, Hannah felt so unwell she could barely hold her newborn daughter in her arms “That feeling was taken away from me,” she said. Despite her symptoms, Hannah was sent home with Pippa the next day and told things should ease up now she’d given birth. But two days later, Hannah’s midwe came to see her and was alarmed. The new mum was bedbound, in unbearable pain and weaker than ever. She told Hannah to go back to hospital for an assessment. “They said I had endometritis and sent me back home,” she said. Endometritis is an inflammation of the lining of the womb which can cause infections after childbirth. Hannah and Jordan were sceptical of the diagnosis but Hannah was too weak to argue. By now, she couldn’t even put Pippa’s dummy in, let alone care for her other kids, Esme, Rory and Phoebe. Days passed and Hannah’s excruciating headaches continued. She was in so much pain she couldn’t move and she was slurring her words.  “I couldn’t move my head because the pain was so bad. It felt like someone was shooting me in the head. Imagine the worst headache of your le,” Hannah described. “I felt like I was dying.” Hannah was unable to sleep and lost the feeling in her right hand. Then, when she began vomiting uncontrollably, an incredibly concerned Jordan took her back to hospital. “He had to carry me into the car because I couldn’t walk,” Hannah said. “Then he dropped me off at AE and took the kids to the supermarket while I waited to be seen.” Finally, Hannah was taken in for a scan. But the results were more chilling than she’d imagined. She recalled: “I sat in a little side room while the doctors sat down in front of me. They told me I had a large brain tumour, andI didn’t have surgery I would die. “I burst into tears and called Jordan immediately to tell him. He came straight to hospital and brought me some clothes because I was being kept in. “It was a strange feeling because I was scared, but also relieved I finally had a diagnosis. I knew it wasn’t an ear infection.”  Hannah was put on steroids to reduce the swelling on her brain. Six days later, she had a  hour operation to remove the tumour and a cyst that was attached to it. Thankfully, the operation was a success and Hannah was allowed to go home a week later. But she had a long road to recovery ahead. “Jordan worked at Jaguar Land Rover at the time and they let him take six months off to look after me. We needed it, because he had to do everything,” Hannah recalled.Their community in Coventry, where the family lived at the time, also rallied around and raised £ for the family through a Facebook group.Luckily, Hannah recovered well, but she had to have another operation a year later in  when she had a build up of fluid in her head, known as pseudomeningocele. The cranioplasty involved draining the fluid from her head and putting an articial bone into her skull to patch up the leak. “There’s a bit of build up of fluid again but I’m hoping I won’t need another operation,” Hannah said. Pippa is now two years old and doing well. Phoebe, five, Rory, seven and Esme, eight, are enjoying school, but Esme worries about her mum sometimes. “She was the oldest at the time so she was slightly more aware of what was happening,” Hannah explained. While Hannah has physically healed well, the mental scars of the trauma have stayed with her. “I suffer from PTSD after what happened. I’m constantly worried I’ll collapse or lose my balance when I go out on my own. “I’ve signed up for free counselling sessions with the Yorkshire Brain Tumour Trust,” she said. Looking back, Hannah said she wouldn’t be here todayshe hadn’t listened to her instincts when she was sick. “I was told I couldn’t possibly have a brain tumour because they’re so rare. But that’s exactly what it was,” she said. She encourages everyone to trust their gutthey think something isn’t right. “People get scared they’re troubling their doctors by making an appointment, butyou know something is wrong, you have to get it checked out.”Do you have a story to share  Email webfeatures@trinitymirror. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA Sikh salesman labelled an Arab shoe bomber in a campaign of vile racist abuse by colleagues is seeking a record tribunal payout of nearly £million. Kieran Sidhu, , was targeted daily by workmates while working for tech firm Exertis in Basingstoke, Hampshire. Mr Sidhu, a Sikh Scotsman of Indian descent, was branded the only ethnic on the team and a temperamental Syrian immigrant who was f***ing for ISIS, a tribunal in Southampton heard. He has already won claims of race discrimination, racial harassment and constructive dismissal. He is seeking £.m in damages after experts said he had suffered such lasting psychological harm from the bullying he may never work again. A tribunal heard Mr Sihdu was subjected to abuse including his sales team ly accusing him of being gay, simulating sex acts with bananas, making lewd remarks about sausages, and trying to make him put on womenaposs lingerie in the office.  His workmates once encouraged him to go out and buy a £ tuxedo for a last-minute aposblack tieapos work event that they knew was, in fact, apossmart casualapos. It is claimed they would routinely sing, to the tune of aposQue Sera Seraapos: aposSidhu, Sidhu, he has a bomb in his shoe, he works at O, he is a f***ing dirty Arabapos. Mr Sidhu quit his job in the firmaposs Basingstoke office in May , suffering from extreme depression and anxiety. The tribunal heard how the harassment escalated from January  after he became an account manager.  The  at Southampton employment tribunal found that three of Mr Sidhuaposs former colleagues - Glynn Smith, Stuart Smith and John Cleary - racially harassed him. Mr Sidhu, who earned £, a year, will seek £,, million for lost earnings, injury to feelings and aggravated damages at a remedy hearing, due to take place in September. The earlier tribunal found that crude sexual innuendo and express sexual reference were considered entertaining banter at the male-orientated workplace. Mr Sidhu told how his team repeatedly taped McDonaldaposs adverts and a spoof male escort business card to his monitor, saying it was what he would be doing once he was sacked.  Glynn Smith referred to Mr Sidhu as f***ing for ISIS and circulated a photo of a bikini-clad woman, said to be aposKieranaposs replacementapos. His team would put Mr Sidhuaposs laptop in the bin, hide his mouse and chair in dferent locations around the office, and stand to applaud whenever he arrived at work late.He said: They thought this was funny but it was embarrassing and disruptive for me. Mr Cleary would deep-throat bananas, saying: aposKieran, you know what time it is. You know you want some, talk dirty to me bitchapos and aposYou must be so hard right now. Thataposs why you wonapost stand up.  Glynn Smith looked up Mr Sidhuaposs house on Google Maps and declared he lived in a s**t area that looks like a terrorist war zone, adding: Whataposs that place called, Aleppo  He also branded Mr Sidhuaposs car the s***est on the team, typed its registration into a used car website and told him they were only offering £. Mr Cleary would accuse Mr Sidhu of using gay dating app Grindr and tried to force him to wear lingerie on the sales floor. Stuart Smith would ask Mr Sidhu: Did you get much sausage last night , how big is your sausage  and do you have sausages in Syria  Colleagues taped pictures of sausages to Mr Sidhuaposs monitor and left post-it notes reading gay boy and a straw hat on his desk saying I love d***. One asked Mr Sidhu how it felt to be the only ethnic on the team and Glynn Smith said: You will be the last ethnicyou are anything to go by. Mr Cleary also sent a team email, suggesting that Mr Sidhu have sex with him in a car park after their work Christmas dinner. Mr Sidhu told his manager his colleaguesapos behaviour was draining and said it could not be dismissed as joking when it was happening daily. He reported a colleague for accepting entertainment in the form of weekend strip club visits, and for routinely showing Mr Sidhu the middle finger and telling him f*** your mum.  The tribunal found manager Matthew Rumsey showed little interest in Mr Sidhuaposs complaints of bullying, caring far more about the teamaposs sales targets. Instead, Mr Rumsey, who was even copied in by colleagues on several of the emails humiliating Mr Sidhu, took client accounts off him and tried to force him out of the firm because he did not fit with the team, the tribunal ruled. After assessing Mr Sidhu, psychiatrist Dr Jonathan Ornstein concluded he has a very low chance of recovery and is unlikely to be able to work again. Mr Sidhuaposs solicitor Lawrence Davies said the size of the claim reflected not only the gravity of the ordeal he suffered but the psychiatric assessment that, in all probability, his career is over. In a statement, Exertis said Mr Sidhuaposs experience was a unique case across a business of more than , employees. It said it had taken appropriate disciplinary action, adding: On this occasion it was clear that certain behaviours within a part of our business fell short of the standards we expect. Many were told they could not go on their pre-booked Ryanair flight to Malaga as they had no proof of Spanish residency. The paperwork, at the time, was required by the Spanish government for people to travel to the country.There were tears of frustration when they were told they could not board the plane, DerbyshireLive reports.The incident happened on Friday but from today, the requirement is no longer in place.  Spain has opened its borders to visitors from countries that have low infection rates, including Britain. A passenger from Derby, who did not wish to be named, told the website things quickly turned toxic. He said: When I arrived at the airport I was asked to go to the Ryanair gate to have my documents checked. I was met by a woman who informed people they would not be travelling unless they had a Spanish passport, proof of an application for residency or a letter from the UK Government saying the trip was essential. This led to anger, aggression and tears and three police officers had to oversee discussions. It was a truly shameful situation that caused great distress and large financial losses to some people. How we can have a validated form from the Spanish Travel Health government site allowing our entry and then be told this isnapost sufficient  This was distressing for many people.  Ryanair has all customersapos email addresses and telephone numbers so they could have contacted all passengers  hours prior to travelling, so this really is shameful and I hope it doesnapost happen to other UK travellers in the future. A spokesman for East Midlands Airport said: On Friday, May ,  passengers were refused boarding onto a flight to Malaga for not having a Spanish residency permit. The decision, taken by the airline’s handling agent, was in line with the requirements of the Spanish authorities at the time.  “We encourage anyone planning to travel overseas to familiarise themselves with what is required of both the destination country and the UK’s regulations prior to booking flights. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeA runaway housewe fleeing an abusive marriage suffered a suspected fractured cheekbone after a family friend who put her up, battered her senseless during a row over unpaid rent. Michelle Prestwich, , was knocked to the floor and beaten by Alvin Williams when he stopped her in the street and demanded she pay him for the six month period she stayed at his flat. During the assault, Williams, , searched Mrs Prestwichaposs pockets before repeatedly punching her to the side of the face. He fled when staff at a nearby shop were alerted and told him to stop. The victim, who also suffered a suspected fractured eye socket in the attack on November  last year, was later rehoused outside the area. In a statement Mrs Prestwich told police: I was scared to death and terried when I was attacked. He is a big bloke, and I thought he would kill me. Still to this day I am having nightmares about this.  I was a victim of domestic violence in the past, and what he has done has brought back so much fear into my le. I have been placed in an area where I do not know anybody and I feel like I have got to start all over again. He has taken away all my independence, she added. At Manchester Crown Court, Williams, from Northenden near Wythenshawe, admitted causing grievous bodily harm and was jailed for  months. He was also banned from contacting Mrs Prestwich for two years under the terms of a restraining order. The court heard Mrs Prestwich had known Williams through her ex-husband and moved in with him when her marriage broke down. Prosecutor Daniel Lister said Mrs Prestwich had become homeless and began staying at friendsapos homes.  She then stayed at Williamsapos flat for six months, paying him £ per fortnight, he said. But not long before the offence happened, Mrs Prestwich moved out and began living with another friend in the same block of flats, the court heard. However, Williams claimed Mrs Prestwich owed him more money for the time she lived with him, Mr Lister said. She was walking with her friend when the defendant appeared on a bicycle, he continued. He screeched to a halt and threw the bike to one side then punched her to the side of her face. She fell back to the floor and he punched her twice more.  The complainantaposs friend went to a local shop to get help. Someone from the shop shouted at him to leave the complainant alone, which he did. The prosecutor said Williams went inside the shop and his victim ed to her friendaposs home and an ambulance was called before she was taken to hospital. Despite her injuries Mrs Prestwich did notto the hospital for follow up appointments so the extent of the suspected facial fractures could not be properly documented. Williams had  previous offences on his record including violence and battery. His lawyer Rachel Cooper said he had since found his Christian faith and wanted a clean slate. She added: The problem with Mrs Prestwich was her associations. It was not that she was causing problems for him, but because of the people she knew, problems were happening at the address. He was worried that it would threaten his tenancy and brought the bad blood between them. Ms Cooper went to say her client is fully remorseful of his actions and he genuinely wants to move on. Judge Mr Recorder Michael Maher said the offence was a nasty act in what appears to have been a chance encounter amid the ongoing dispute. She previously has been the victim of domestic violence, and you knew that because you provided her accommodation to escape that, he continued. Jeremy Sturant was just  when he struck a deal that could have made him a multi-millionaire today. Instead, unaware of how big Bitcoin would become, he used up the crypto cash to cover expenses on a business trip – and the day has gone down in crypto currency history. Bitcoin Pizza Day, as it has come to be known, was celebrated this Saturday on the th anniversary of the fateful transaction. On  May , in the first documented purchase of physical goods with Bitcoin, Sturant answered a message on the Bitcointalk chat forum in  from hungry Bitcoin pioneer Laszlo Hanyecz.  It read: Iaposll pay , Bitcoins for a couple of pizzas... like maybe  large ones so I have some left over for the next day. I like having left over pizza to nibble on later. “You can make the pizza yourself and bring it to my house or order it for me from a delivery place, but what Iaposm aiming for is getting food delivered in exchange for bitcoins where I donapost have to order or prepare it myself. The message continues: I like things like onions, peppers, sausage, mushrooms, tomatoes, pepperoni, etc.. just standard stuff no weird fish topping or anything like that.  Hanyecz said: If youaposre interested please let me know and we can work out a deal. Sturant, from Calornia, US, stepped up to the plate, ordering two large supreme pizzas infor , Bitcoin.That sum was worth only about £ at the time, as The Sun reports. Today those coins would be worth around £,,.The cryptocash disappeared when Sturant used it to cover expenses while travelling the US with his girlfriend. He has said he “certainly” regrets it today – but argues he was simply “facilitating a purchase” at the time. Sturant said in : “At the time of the famous pizza I would never have thought that the same number of bitcoin would have a purchasing power on the order of real estate, or that major companies would accept bitcoin automatically for day-to-day transactions.  He said: That matters to me more than being worth a particular number of GBP, EUR, or USD.” For his part, Hanyecz said he felt like he was winning the internet that day. He has said: I donapost regret it. I think that itaposs great that I got to be part of the early history of Bitcoin in that way.FOLLOW USDailyMirrorFollow @DailyMirrorCOMMENTSAdd CommentMore OnPizzaBitcoin

which include four classrooms located in the main school building.Head teacher Maxine Barwick said: “It has been amazing to have all the children back in school, working away and learning together.“The building is bright and modern, but still feels like the primary school we all know and love so I’m delighted to get the first week under our belts and see all the children happy to be back home.”The structure, which dates back to , was restored and refurbished by Stirling Council who worked closely with a conservation architect and the Loch Lomond and Trossachs National Park Planning Authority.The renovation came after the primary school was identied in September  as one of the five major investment education infrastructure priorities approved based on building condition and sustainability by Stirling Council’s Children and Young People Committee.With initial renovations to the  capacity building, set to start in spring , delayed due to lockdown, the children and to thank them for their patience and understanding.”Vice Convener, Councillor Christine Simpson said: “The completion of this ambitious project will give a new lease of le to this building which was and even throw-in won was greeted by cheers of encouragement.The manager and players said they felt there were more like , there than  and the supporters most certainly played their part in victory revealed she suffered an ectopic pregnancy which led to emergency surgery.Updating her followers of more than , on Instagram, Cara explained surgeons had to remove one of her fallopian tubes after it ruptured.The ruptured fallopian tube caused the former The Only Way Is Essex star to have a potentially le-threatening internal bleed. The mum-of-two added she is now back in hospital for kidney stone treatment.According to the NHS, in the UK around one in every  pregnancies end up being ectopic # that equates to around , pregnancies a year.An ectopic pregnancy is caused by a fertilised egg implanting itself outside of the womb, usually in a woman#s fallopian tube.If an egg becomes stuck in a fallopian tube then the baby won#t develop and a woman#s le can be at riskthe condition were to go undetected.Sadly, an ectopic pregnancy means the baby cannot be saved. The fertilised egg will need to be removed. In order to do so, surgeons will either perform an operation or a woman will be given an injection of methotrexate which stops the pregnancy growing.Some women will never know the concrete facts behind what caused them to suffer an ectopic pregnancy.However, there are some factors which can increase the risk of an ectopic pregnancy.These factors include pelvic inflammatory disease , having a previous ectopic pregnancy, previous surgery on the fallopian tubes, fertility treatment such as IVF , falling pregnant while using an intrauterine device for contraception, falling pregnant over the age of , and smoking.If symptoms do appear, they tend to develop between weeks four and  of pregnancy. On occasion, an ectopic pregnancy won#t present any symptoms and may only be picked up during an ultrasound scan.Symptoms can include tummy pain low down on one side, vaginal bleeding or a brown watery discharge, shoulder tip pain, or discomfort when passing urine or stools.However, it#s important to know these symptoms may not always mean there is an ectopic pregnancy and could be caused by other conditions.Like Cara Kilbey, sometimes an ectopic pregnancy can be le threatening and may require emergency treatment.Fortunately, it#s uncommon for an ectopic pregnancy to result in a fallopian tube rupturing . Butit does occur the fallopian tube will need to be repaired or removed as soon as possible.A ruptured fallopian tube may cause one or more of the following symptoms a sharp, sudden and intense abdominal pain, feeling dizzy, sick or fainting or looking very pale.If a person suspects a rupture they should call  immediately.Suffering an ectopic pregnancy is traumatic and can cause a great deal of grief and stress for both a woman and her family.It#s important during such a dficult time to seek help and support from family and friends.A number of support groups are also available for women and their families to contact following a pregnancy loss.NHS Grampian guides women who have suffered from an ectopic pregnancy to a number of dferent support groups. The health board also offers the opportunity to speak to a bereavement support midwe for the area. The midwe can be contacted via Aberdeen Royal Infirmary or a community midwe.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

businessman has launched a new learning tool to improve children#s surgery in Africa.Garreth Wood and his we Nicola launched the Kids Operating Roomfive years ago and their latest project will help trainee surgeons learn the latest techniques.The  has been built by the Royal College of Surgeons of Irelandusing the expertise of more than  African surgeons and will be used in  nations in west, central, east and southern Africa.The free tool will give trainees tips on the latest techniques, pathologies and equipment to help improve their skill-set so they can specialise in much needed paediatric surgery.Garreth Wood, chairman of KidsOR, said: #We committed to deliver this project after listening to the wishes of trainees across the continent.#The mentor-based training regime of surgeons is excellent, but no one mentor can be the best at everything. This  gives trainees access to the continent’s leading surgeons for each subject.#We are so grateful to have had such a great team work on this project, collaborating alongside COSECSA and WACS # who were able to make the  as comprehensive # and relevant # as possible.#It’s the first  that’s fundamentally created by African surgeons for African surgeons, which we hope will support and enhance existing mentor-based training systems.“Ultimately our ambition is to find the gaps and find the best ways to support junior doctors through their studies with resources to help drive the quality, skill-sets and confidence of new graduates.#We want to help scale the workforce and this  will allow recent and updated research and techniques to be shared by professionals to support trainees.#KidsOR was founded by Mr Wood and his we Nicola in  and creates modern, safe surgical theatres in developing countries. Each year, more children in Africa die of surgically treatable injuries than HIV, TB and Malaria combined.Professor Emmanuel Ameh, chief consultant paediatric surgeon at National Hospital in Abuja, said: #The e-learning  is coming at a time of increased momentum in efforts to scale up access to safe, affordable and timely surgical care for children.#It is unique in that it’s more than a textbook, it leverages technology to provide an engaging and rewarding learning experience. That data is supported by further research, carried out specically in rural Scotland, which additionally showed higher support for onshore wind power among young people.#The question posed by the surveyor should, of course, have been: #Are you opposed to further development of onshore wind #In Scotland today we have , operational turbines# that#s more than the rest of the UK put together.We also have , consented  under construction and a further , in the planning system according to an FOI response from the Scottish Government.These figures change on an almost daily basis as applications continue to pile in unabated.How many people are going to continue to support onshore wind when they witness the total annihilation of this country It would also be interesting to know exactly where the data from #rural Scotland# was collected. Was it perhaps in an area where there were no wind farms in sight of  the local communities which were questioned but where they were still able to take advantage of any community benefit on offer If successful, the public petition recently submitted to the Scottish Parliament by campaign group Scotland Against Spin should help to clary exactly how much support there really is for further onshore wind development in Scotland.Aileen Jackson, Knockglass, UplawmoorSir,I have been contacted by a number of my justiably concerned constituents about the recent removal of a cattle grid on the Isle of Gigha from the road between the ferry jetty and the village.The space has been tarred over but I have been informed by residents that unfortunately the sub surface area was just grit and so the tar has subsided due to traffic including tractors and lorries. The dip now is actually worse than when the cattle grid was in place.To make matters worse, the damaged cattle grid which is now mangled metal has been left on the adjacent roadside verge.It is my strong belief thatcattle grids are damaged the roads department should replace them with new, fit-for-propose cattle grids, not get rid of them all together.Not only should road repairs be made to last, but at the very least the roads department should clean up after itself and remove old damaged materials # such as this # left behind. If a private company or an inidual member of the public left a large amount of scrap metal at the side of the road they would be in trouble.I have contacted our roads# management through member services and asked them to recty this matter as soon as possible.Councillor Alastair Redman, Kintyre and the Islands ward Sir,I am a GP in one of Argyll’s rural practices. Last week I was having a busy morning so was a little later than usual getting back to my car, which I had left charging at an electric charge point.That evening I was surprised to see that I’d been charged £ over and above the normal charging rate per KwH. I checked through the Argyll and Bute website and discovered that there is now an overstay charge – hence the surcharge.I had had an email back in April saying that Argyll and Bute Council would now be charging users at its charge points – the cost being p per KwH. Fair enough.However, there was no mention of a penalty for overstaying. Nor is there any notice at the charge points themselves, save a tiny notice stating #charges apply#.Those seeking to charge in Argyll and Bute are additionally confused by the lack of clarity over what type of charge point is being used: is it a  Kw, Kw or a  Kw. There is no notice on the chargers. This is important because the overstay timings y according to the dfering units.When I buy petrol at a filling station I clearly know what the charges are when I buy a ticket at a parking meter, I buy a ticket and know exactly how long I am able to park there.But it seems that for electric vehicles you have to search the internet to find out the rules – and in my village there is no local wi and  I cannot get G on my phone.Dr Carina Spink, MuasdaleSir,Cats Protection would like to advise cat owners to be aware of the risks posed to their cat by the sun.Pale-coloured cats, or those with unpigmented white noses or ears, are particularly at risk from the sun’s rays which can cause sunburn and skin cancer.Those affected can suffer long term damage including, in severe cases, having to have their ear tips removed to prevent the cancer from spreading.Following a few simple tips, owners can help to protect their cat from the harmful effects of the sun.These include keeping them indoors on sunny days between am and pm, asking your vet for advice about suitable sunscreen and ensuring you provide plenty of shade to enable your cat to shelter from the sun’s rays.Dr Sarah Elliott, Central Veterinary Officer, Cats Protection

Thanks you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging timeWe value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Remember what they say about reading the small print  It can keep you out of trouble and may even save your le.I’ve been reading the Scottish Government report on the future of the NHS, the primary care part. This is all the stuff in the community that helps us to keep well and directs us to hospitalwe need that sort of care. It involves GPs, nurses, an army of health professionals and lots of support staff. It is essentialwe are to achieve what the publicsay is a priority, enjoying a healthy le. As the founders of the NHS said: #From the cradle to the grave#.Hiding in plain sight in this report, in the small print, is this statement: #Politicians, health care professionals and the public must all be involvedour primary care system is to survive.# As Oprah Winfrey would put it, #WHAT # If this is what is at stake, why have we not heard more about it  Why was it enough to contact so few people among our erse population Why has health management locally cast our group out in the cold We are open to all and represent a wide cross section of community interests. And their latest distancing act is to #temporarily suspend# public representation on its Integration Joint Board.I am coming to believe that this critical situation has overtaken long-held belief systems that need to be challenged.In NHS values, the first statement is #working together for patients.#That is well out of date increasingly the patient has been a participator in their care, and the duty of obtaining consent means you can’t have treatment without co-operation.This report goes on to make clear that #collaboration# is a key requirement. That means we are an essential part of the system.It seems clear that we are going to have to fight to get past the unconscious assumptions of decision makers. It is literally a fight for the lives of ourselves and generations after us.We need all the support we can get.

your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowInveraray Castle is planning to reopen its doors for the season on May .After a limited season in  and a delayed start to , the family and team at Inveraray Castle are delighted that the house will be open to visitors after so long.Home to the Dukes of Argyll and the seat of the clan Campbell, Inveraray Castle is one of Scotland’s most visited and recognised buildings.Inspired by Vanbrugh # of Castle Howard and Blenheim Palace # its baroque, Palladian and gothic style is fairytale in design while the interiors include exquisite hand painted walls and ceilings.French tapestries still hang in the rooms they were intended for a soaring -metre high room displays arms in the Armoury Hall and there are items from Queen Victoria and her daughter Princess Louiseas well as a room dedicated to the clan Campbell.The Campbell family has been a key part of Scottish and British events since their arrival in the s and the experienced team of guides will be on hand to bring the family’s extraordinary history to le with anecdotes and explanations.From Robert the Bruce to clan wars, Rob Roy, royalty, scandals and even the paranormal, the family and house have played a major part through British history.The castle gardens will also open, extending to  acres of formal lawns and flower beds as well as  hectares of park and woodland.One of the most important designed landscapes in Scotland, the garden is famous for its rhododendrons and azaleas as well as trees planted by distinguished visitors in the past.Planned walks are throughout the estate including one up Dun na Cuaiche overlooking the castle, Inveraray town, Loch Fyne and the majesty of the west Highlands.The estate will be open for those who wish just to walk in the grounds and both the shop, coffee shop and parking will be available to non-castle visitors.Torquhil Argyll, the th duke, said: #We have spent the closed months preparing for the reopening and welcoming back visitors.#We have missed the energy and buzz that a visitor brings with them. Inveraray Castle was one of the first stately homes ever to open its doors in  and we can’t wait to share our home and history with visitors again.#The castle will be opened with the safety of the visitor in mind.Covid regulations will be adhered to and there will be regular cleaning, hand sanitising stations and contactless payments, while an online booking system will reduce the chance of overcrowding.
