story: PORTAFERRY man Patsy Mullan idolised his big brother, Fr Hugh Mullan, who was shot dead by soldiers in what became known as the Ballymurphy Massacre nearly  years ago.He and his surviving brother, Sean, who lives in England, and the wider family never got over Fr Mullanrsquos untimely death at the age of .ldquoOur parents never recovered from it and to be honest I still find it dficult to talk about it because we were so close, said the  year-old.Fr Mullan had been a curate at Corpus Christie Church in Ballymurphy for seven months when he died on August  .Mr Mullan and his niece, Geraldine McGrattan, were in Belfast last Tuesday to hear a coroner finally acknowledge mdash contrary to what the Army said at the time mdash that Fr Mullan was not carrying any weapons and had only ldquopeaceful intentions when he tended to a wounded man during a gun battle.Mrs Justice Keegan told the families: ldquoIrsquom quite convinced he was a peacemaker, he went to help an injured man and he had warned the army what was happening, adding that at the time he was shot, ldquoIt was still light and it was clear he was a priest.Mr Mulllan said: ldquoI knew all along that Hugh was innocent, although there is always a little hesitation with how the law works, but I was confident enough that he and all of them would be cleared of what happened as they were shot by the Army.ldquoHugh was always in contact with the family, in fact the day he died he phoned my mother and told her not to be coming up to see him as there was trouble. That was the last we heard from him.ldquoI was listening to the news all afternoon to hearthere was anything happening. It wasnrsquot until pm that night when I was listening to the RTE news that I heard a priest had been shot in Ballymurphy.Mr Mullan knew in his gut that it was his brother, but could not bring himself to tell his parents, John and Mary.ldquoAll that was said that he was shot, it didnrsquot say he was dead. He was actually dead within  minutes of being shot, he continued.ldquoWe were phoned around am and I found out he was dead. I called the doctor just in case my mother would get badly upset and she was badly upset after the doctor told her. I couldnrsquot bring myself to tell her.ldquoMy father was up the stairs and couldnrsquot come down the stairs but he knew it was bad news.Mr Mullan said it took the Ballymurphy families a few years to organise in order to campaign for truth and justice as a  inquest recorded an open verdict in all the deaths.He has been involved with the campaign for a new inquest for over  years, travelling to Dublin and Brussels and beyond on order to plead the familiesrsquo case.Mr Mullan, his niece Geraldine McGrattan and son Hugh had been regular attenders over the  days the inquest was held.The family, including Mr Mullanrsquos late sister Teresa, lived for a time on the Strand, beside the Portaferry Hotel.While Mr Mulllan took after his father and spent his working le fishing, Fr Mullan spent a year in the Merchant Navy before opting to go to Queenrsquos University and then Maynooth College to train to be a priest.He served for a time at St Josephrsquos Church in Killough before moving to Dunloy for nine years. While his funeral was held in Belfast, he was buried in St Patrickrsquos graveyard in Portaferry.ldquoHugh baptised all my family, he married me and my we Mary, so he was very close to us all, said Mr Mullan.He recalled how his brother loved to sail in Strangford Lough and entertain his family or parishioners by singing along to his guitar.But most of all, Mr Mullan mourns what his brother could have done for others.ldquoHugh was the type of priest who needed to be among people all the time, helping people, he said.ldquoHe was someone who would have given anyone anything he had, even his last penny. He particularly liked to help young people and loved working and encouraging them.ldquoIf he had have got a chance in Ballymurphy, he would have helped the people no end to help themselves. Thatrsquos what he aimed to do with people and was always thinking of dferent things that he could start.Mr Mullan thanked everybody who had called him or send cards over the week and in particular, local priest, Fr Feargal McGrady, for his help and support over the years.Mr Mullanrsquos granddaughter, Mairead OrsquoHare, added: ldquoThese families have fought so tirelessly over the years to get justice for their loved ones, it has been both inspiring and heartbreaking to watch.ldquoI never met my great-uncle, but the stories my Granda tells regularly make his presence known and you can easily tell that the love my Granda has for his brother has never ceased.ldquoHe has known for the last  years that his brother was innocent, he didnrsquot need a coronerrsquos ruling to know that, but having Fr Mullan declared innocent to the entire world has brought much needed comfort and peace..prettyPhoto

title: ‘World knows Hugh was innocent’
story: THE family of Ballymurphy Massacre victim Fr Hugh Mullan have welcomed a coronerrsquos ruling that he was an innocent ldquopeacemaker.The Portaferry priest was shot dead by soldiers as he tended to a wounded man on waste ground in west Belfast on August  .Fr Mullan and nine others shot dead were all exonerated in an inquest ruling by a coroner last week.At the time the Army reported that the nine men and one woman who died were Republican gunmen killed in crossfire.The first to die over the three days of shooting, Fr Mullan had only served a a church for seven months.Mrs Justice Keegan said in her findings that he was ldquounarmed, not acting in any way as a threat, attending to a wounded man in the field and waving a white object as a sign of his peaceful intentions.ldquoHe died as a result of gunshot wounds to the chest and abdomen. The shooting of the deceased has not been justied by the State. The use of force by the Army that resulted in his death was disproportionate.Fr Mullanrsquos youngest brother, Patsy, said that he and the rest of his family always knew the  year-old priest was innocent.Now , he said the first learnt something was wrong when he heard that a priest had been shot in Ballymurphy that day on the RTE late news.ldquoI knew right away it would be him, he was the type of person and would be out to help anyone in trouble or who was injured. That was just his nature. Unfortunately it was his downfall, said Mr Mullan, who still lives in Portaferry.ldquoHugh was the type of priest who would have been among people all the time, helping people.ldquoHe was someone who would have given anyone anything he had, even his last penny.Mr Mullan was left unimpressed with an apology that Prime Minister Boris Johnston made in a call to former First Minister Arlene Foster.ldquoI wouldnrsquot have wanted an apology from him actually. I donrsquot have much time for him at the best of times because I donrsquot think hersquos the best person for that job.Mr Mullan, his niece Geraldine McGrattan, his son Hugh and other family members attended nearly all  days the inquest since it started in November .Mrs McGrattan said that hearing the judgersquos findings ldquolted a weight of me.ldquoIrsquove known for the past  years that Hugh was innocent but now the world knows, she said.ldquoTo hear him call him a peacemaker was very touching. It was as though that I had been coiled up in a tight spring and suddenly just released. It was a great day..prettyPhoto

title: Ardglass fishermen sign up to marine litter project
story: A NEW initiative has been launched which aims to reduce the amount of litter in the sea.Spearheaded by the Northern Ireland Fishery Harbour Authority, a number of trawler owners based in Ardglass have signed up for the new lsquoFishing for Litterrsquo scheme designed to help protect marine le.The village hosted a launch of the new scheme with trawler skippers and Fishery Harbour Authority officials last Friday and were joined by representatives from the Northern Ireland Fish Producersrsquo Association.The lsquofishing for litterrsquo scheme is designed to reduce the amount of marine litter by physically removing it, with the new initiative also highlighting the importance of good waste management amongst the fleet.Participating vessels are given hardwearing bags to collect marine litter that is caught in their nets during their normal fishing activities, with the waste subsequently deposited at participating harbours on the quayside where they are moved to a dedicated skip for recycling or disposal which has a positive impact on the environment.The scheme is being launched at the three Co Down ports of Ardglass, Portavogie and Kilkeel with fishermen highlighting their frustration about marine litter which can be found in rivers, lakes and seas across the globe.A walk along any coastline will reveal a rainbow of colour where there should just be sand and stones with plastic the real reason that marine litter is such a big issue.Jenny Lau mdash the Fishery Harbour Authorityrsquos environment officer who was in Ardglass last Friday mdash explained that a plastic bottle is typically used for less than  minutes before being discarded, after which it takes  years to break down.ldquoEven then, it will break down into smaller and smaller pieces known as micro plastics which are still harmful. This means that plastic litter in the sea is just adding up and, globally, we are adding a truck load full every minute, she continued.ldquoThat is a lot of plastic and, on top of looking bad, it is harmful to sea plants and animals. Every year, plastic kills , sea animals and over a million sea birds. It is a big problem.During last weekrsquos launch event in Ardglass, a number of fishermen told Jenny how sad they were to see how much litter is in the sea and that they have noticed an increase in the amount of it in during their letimes.ldquoIt also takes their valuable time at sea to clear from their nets and can potentially contaminate their catch, so the new scheme is a win-win for them to do their part in getting rid of it.Describing the new project as ldquoinnovative, Jenny said it has already been successful where with fishermen bringing marine litter caught in their nets back to shore.She said the Harbour Authority provides durable bags for the litter to be collected in and that once landed onshore, it is sent off to be recycled or otherwise disposed of.ldquoThis is how our fishermen in Northern Ireland are reducing the marine plastic problem at sea, Jenny explained. ldquoThe thing that makes this project so unique is that fishermen are almost the only people who have access to litter that is out in the open water or at the seabed.ldquoStopping waste entering the sea is imperative, but taking litter out of the sea is too, even though it is more challenging. That is exactly what lsquofishing for litterrsquo fishermen do.Jenny praised the fishermen in Ardglass who have signed up to the scheme as did local councillor, Dermot Curran.ldquoThis is a great scheme and anything which can help reduce the amount of marine litter being washed ashore is to be welcomed, he said.ldquoTen Ardglass skippers have already signed up for the scheme and I hope that there will be more. This is a great new initiative but we also have to look at how litter gets into the sea in the first place which poses problems for trawler skippers as this waste gets tangled up in their nest which is time-consuming and a distraction they could well do without, he said.ldquoThe Fishery Harbour Authority is to be congratulated for bringing this initiative to the Co Down ports and the more skippers that sign up for lsquofishing for litterrsquo the better. The scheme can help protect the environment and reduce the amount of unsightly litter being washed up along the shoreline..prettyPhoto

title: Business support programme helps secure 78 jobs in district
story: A COUNCIL-LED local business support programme has created  jobs in the last  months.According to new figures released, the Business Growth and Tender for Growth programmes facilitated by Newry, Mourne and Down District Council have helped to create an average of one new job each week.The programmes are part-funded by Invest Northern Ireland and the European Regional Development Fund under the Investment for Growth  Jobs Northern Irelandprogramme.Despite the impact of recent lockdowns over the last  months, NMD Business has continued to provide SMEs with support packages in response to challenges created by the pandemic.This has resulted in ongoing growth for the business and the creation of  new job roles, as well as helping  businesses involved in the programme to navigate an unprecedented economic environment.Participants in the programme are able to avail of one-to-one mentoring from leading experts, who help guide them and their business through unprecedented times, as well as learning new skills in financial management, cross-border sales and maximising your chances of winning tenders.As a result, many businesses have been able to not only grow their business, but grow their workforce.Sara Velasquez, from Ecoplastic in Downpatrick, completed the programme last year and has already recruited four new staff for the business.Her firm designs and makes all kinds of structures from % recycled material, from boardwalks to street furniture, bridges to bike trails and picnic tables.She said: ldquoThe NMD Business programme helped us focus on the most lucrative areas for growth for our business.ldquoOur dedicated mentor provided us with expert guidance which allowed us to respond quickly to a new market environment, giving us confidence that decisions we were taking were anchored in good commercial sense, while the workshops equipped us with new skills that will stand us in good stead into the future.ldquoSales have since increased as a result and we continue to work on exciting projects across Ireland and the UK. Thanks to this success, we have already recruited  new people into production and logistics roles and are looking forward to growing our team even further as it continues.ldquoFor any businesses who think they may need a helping hand, whether for marketing, accounting administration, tendering or winning new customers, this is the programme for you. Registration is free, however, the experience and contacts you gain from it are invaluable.Speaking on the success of the business support programme, council chairwoman Laura Devlin said: ldquoAs a council we want to see the success of local businesses, who can create jobs and compete in local and international markets.ldquoThat is why the NMD Business Growth and Tender for Growth programmes are important elements of our work, where we can support SMEs and start-ups to develop their skills and grow their business.She added: ldquoIt is great to see that the programme is a success, with so many of the hundreds who have taken part seeing growth and expansion of their businesses in the last  months.ldquoIt is particularly exciting to see  new jobs created, one each week since the programme launched, and we hope to see even more in the coming months.For more information visit www.nmdbusiness.org growing-your-business..prettyPhoto

title: Captain Connor secures victory
story: DUNDRUM seconds made it a hat-trick of league wins for the club over the weekend by beating Cregagh thirds by  runs on Sunday.On a wet afternoon at The Meadow, Cregagh won the toss and elected to field first.Dundrum opened the batting with Jack Calvert and Scott Symington. Dundrum lost Calvert early on after he got a good quick delivery from Max Shannon .Connor Moag came to the crease and looked to put pressure on the bowlers, hitting two quick boundaries before he was bowled by M Keenanfor eight. This left Dundrum  for two in the first three overs.Dundrum skipper Lee Connor joined Symington at the crease and the two batsmen took the score to  from seven overs.Dundrum lost three quick wickets in the form of Connor , Symingtonand new batsman Peter Calvert . This left the home side  for five at the ten over mark.Gordy Lowey and Rahul Sodhi combined well to add  runs. However, both batsmen fell in the th over to the bowling of C Allen .Dundrum lost a further two wickets in the following over to the bowling of N Pinkerton . This left Dundrum - in the sixteenth over and looking atthe possibility of posting a below par score.Stephen Campbell and Dave Crudgington added  vital runs for the final wicket to take Dundrum to  for nine from their  overs. Campbell played aggressively to finish on  from only  balls while Crudgington finished on nine not out. Dundrum needed to field and bowl well to restrict Cregagh.Dundrum opened the bowling with Rahul Sodhi and Symington, while Cregagh opened the batting with N Kelly and S Mackie.Dundrum started with a blast, reducing Cregagh to  for four inside the first six overs. Sodhi picked up three wickets bowling with fantastic pace and control. Symington picked up the other wicket.Cregagh attempted to counter attack however Connor came into the attack and picked up two wickets in one over to put all the pressure on Cregagh.Cregagh never recovered from their poor start and, combined with good Dundrum bowling and fielding, they eventually finished  runs short.The pick of the bowlers was Sodhi, who finished with three for eight from his four overs. Sodhi was well supported by Conorand Gordy Lowey .A fantastic win for the seconds as they continue their push for promotion this season. The win on Sunday meant all three Dundrum senior teams won their league games this weekend.Dundrum secondsrsquo next game is on Thursday evening when they host Donacloney Mill in a rescheduled league game.The club would like to thank all their sponsors and volunteers for their continued support..prettyPhoto

title: CCTV plans to help address dog fouling
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council is progressing plans to use CCTV and arm its enforcement staff with bodycams in a bid to help address the districtrsquos dog fouling and fly-tipping issues.Local politicians will be told tonight that the proposal is one of the key planks of a new enforcement improvement plan which the organisation is spearheading.The news will be confirmed at a meeting of the local authorityrsquos Neighbourhood Services Committee but plans to use DNA testing on dog dirt in a bid to trace animals whose owners allow them to use public areas as open air toilets has been ruled out.The lsquopoodunnitrsquo enforcement plan was approved in March and as Covid restrictions continue to ease, councillors are keen to see the programme rolled out to address two issues which they receive the most complaints about.Two new enforcement staff are due to be in place before the end of this month, while consideration is also being given to providing additional litter bins across the district, along with plans to raise public awareness of the need to address both issues.Plans to appoint so-called community ambassadors to help address the dog fouling and fly-tipping issues have been hampered by Covid with a new council communications plan set to be rolled out next month.The plan will initially concentrate on dog fouling before focusing on the anti-litter message, while a dedicated page focusing on responsible on responsible dog ownership will be posted on the local authority website.In addition, council officials will be using the local authorityrsquos social media pages to spread the word about the need to act, while there are plans to develop an education programme to be rolled out across the districtrsquos schools highlighting the health and environmental hazards of dog fouling, littering and fly-tipping.Rowallane councillor Billy Walker mdash who has consistently raised the issues of dog fouling and fly-tipping mdash has welcomed the council initiative and appealed to the public to be more responsible when it comes to cleaning up after their pets and disposing of their household waste.He said council officials are working with the Environment Agency and are keen to get on top of the fly-tipping issue in particular which costs ratepayers tens of thousands of pounds a year to deal with.ldquoCouncillors across the entire Newry, Mourne and Down area are regularly told about fly tipping and dog fouling issues which we need to address effectively. They have been allowed to continue for too long.ldquoPotentially using body cams and CCTV to apprehend offenders is welcome but, as I have consistently argued, there is a need to beef up existing legislation and work alongside other bodies to examine how they have successfully dealt with the problem.The politician said everyone had a responsibility and a duty of care to make sure their rubbish doesnrsquot end up being illegally dumped and to clean up after their pets.ldquoThere is simply no excuse for not doing so, Cllr Walker declared. ldquoWhile most people dispose of their waste properly and clean the mess that their pets create, there are many who donrsquot, caring little for the environment, the districtrsquos appearance or the cost of cleaning up after them. We need affirmative action so those who blatantly disregard the law are made accountable.Cllr Walker said dog dirt posed a major health risk to children who could potentially lose their sight as a result of coming into contact with it.He added: ldquoWhile the council has been told that the DNA testing of dog dirt is not feasible as the local authority has no legal power to insist that dog owners register for the service, we still have to get to grips with this issue.ldquoThe enforcement improvement plan is welcome, but it would be so much easier of dog owners cleaned up after their pets. While the vast majority do, there are those who donrsquot, caring little for childrenrsquos health, the environment and their own community..prettyPhoto

title: Consultants finalising Rock Pool costs report
story: A MAJOR report detailing the cost of repairing Newcastlersquos crumbling Rock Pool has still not been completed, it was confirmed this week.Newry, Mourne and Down Council revealed on Monday that it is still waiting on the consultantsrsquo report and that it could be several more weeks before they have an opportunity to study it in granular detail.Over the past few months, consultants have been involved in a painstaking examination of the outdoor seawater pool, pouring over every inch of the structure to determine the exact cost of bringing it back into public use.Preliminary investigation work at the pool mdash which enjoys protected status and opened in the early s mdash has revealed that there are a number of issues which require urgent attention and that considerable costs are involved.It is understood that the detailed survey focused on the poolrsquos structural integrity and that a number of options for the poolrsquos future are on the table for discussion.Earlier this year, it was reported that the poolrsquos concrete structure has extensively degraded, while the system to filter sea water is almost unusable, with seawater pipes so corroded that rust is coming off them and contaminating the water being filtered.In addition, the pool is unable to retain water as a result of cracks in the concrete and has been described as no longer fit-for-purpose, with one of the most signicant concerns for council officials that the pool does not comply with current health and safety standards, with suggestions that a complete rebuild may required.Last month, the local authority said it hoped to receive the consultantsrsquo reports within in a matter of weeks with speculation suggesting that it could now be June before officials get their hands on the document.A council spokesman has confirmed to the Recorder that while it has not yet received the report, ldquoit is expected in the coming weeks.Earlier this year, a local politician suggested that the final bill mdash including all the necessary repairs and health and safety upgrades mdash could top the poundm mark.The local authority has previously insisted that it remains committed to ldquoexploring all funding opportunities to assist with financing the repair costs.Money to help finance the outdoor poolrsquos repair costs is included in Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos budget for the new financial year, but it is believed that it may not be enough to cover the final bill which will require help from other funders, potentially the Heritage Lottery Fund.When completed, the consultantsrsquo report will initially be considered by the local authorityrsquos Active and Healthy Communities Committee which will then make recommendations to the full council on how to proceed with the repairs and, signicantly, how they will be funded..prettyPhoto

title: Declan living in seventh heaven
story: ON Sunday, May , East Down ACrsquos Declan Teague took on his first marathon since lockdown.He had kept up his training throughout the periods of restrictions and posted a decent time in a half marathon the week before, so when East Antrim marathon series announced an event, he was ready to step up to the next level.Thirty runners took on the tough course in and around Greenisland. It was a four-lap course which started at Greenisland Golf Club and carried on via Monkstown Wood, Shore Road and then a bit of a challenge with a hill to contend with on Station Road.The weather was grey with a little drizzle but nothing to cause major problems and in fact Declan felt that there was a slight wind assistance on the climb which was welcome.The overall winner Chris Denton, was the only runner to break three hours and he took top spot on the podium with a time of two hours and  minutes.Declan was more than happy with his own time of . and the fact that he placed seventh overall. Another marathon to add to his tally.The following Sunday, EDAC was once again represented at marathon distance, this time at Down Royal where Glenn Grant of ChampionChip was hosting events that were called off when lockdown hit.There were two races on offer, a K and a marathon distance, and it was the . miles which attracted Gordy Graham. He turned up well prepped and targeting an ambitious but achievable two hours  minutes.His training in lockdown has been consistent despite having a newborn in the house and he is quick to pay tribute to his partner, Steph, who has supported his frequent absences during long training runs.The fact that she is a runner herself explains her understanding attitude and Gordy no doubt get his chance to pay back when the time comes for her own training to recommence.There was a compact field of  for the marathon and Gordy was in good company as other runners were also hoping to achieve fast times.They all settled into their respective rhythms and at half way it appeared that Gordy was bang on the button with the clock showing .. but as those who have run this distance know, it is not over till you reach the line and in a race this long both mental and physical factors can take their toll.There was a stf headwind along one side of each of the eight laps which had an accumulative effect and around the  mile mark, Gordy found it increasingly hard to maintain his pace.He was not the only one as the lead runner, John Kinsella, who was hoping for . had to lsquosettlersquo for . at the finish, and Joe Lillis, who came second, was also wide of his aspired time when he clocked ..In the end Gordy held on for third place in ... This represents a -second improvement on his best time, but he confessed to feeling disappointed as given his performances in training and his current fitness levels he felt that he had more in him, just not on that day.No doubt he will be in discussions with coach Ryan Maxwell to analyse his race but surely the lack of crowds and other runners must be the biggest hurdle to pulling out best times.If London Marathon gets the go ahead in September he will have another crack at it and East Down wish him the best in his training going forward.On Saturday, Suzy Smith was the sole EDAC representative at a race. She had been persuaded by her brother, Patrick, to run the . mile event at Florida Manor.This race was the prelude to the last one standing event hosted by Atlas running. The route was testing as it was far from flat with a mix of trail, tarmac, gravel path, grass and wood chips.When she realised there were fewer than  taking part, she was tempted toout for fear of getting left behind but afterwards she said that it was quite enjoyable.It is testament to the progress that Suzy has made that not only did she convince herself to show up but also that she was far from last.Although there was a small crowd taking part, there was a great atmosphere with other runners getting ready for endurance races later on in the day.There were no results at the time of going to press, but as Suzy said this was more about feeling of achievement rather than a time and she was glad that she had made the effort to take part..prettyPhoto

title: Down go again
story: DOWN senior footballers will be aiming to claim their first win since theirto Division Two this Sunday when they face Meath.Paddy Tallyrsquos men lost their opening game of this seasonrsquos campaign away to Mayo in Castlebar last Saturday, whilst Meath claimed a narrow one point win over neighbours Westmeath.Down will be aiming to take the positives from last weekendrsquos clash ahead of Sundayrsquos fixture having been praised for their hearty display against a Mayo side hotly tipped for promotion back to the big time.Substitute Stephen McConville scored a late consolation goal in Downrsquos recent outing and although his strike didnrsquot impact the outcome of the game, it showed that the side is notprepared to stop fighting until the final whistle.Tally will also draw comfort from his sidersquos opening quarter display as they managed to hold the Mayo team to a stalemate before they eventually were broken down.This Sundayrsquos clash will serve as a clearer barometer of the Mourne menrsquos level and they kniow that two defeats on the bounce would leave them in a calamitous situation.Meath manager Andy McEntee will have plenty of positives to take from his teamrsquos weekend win in Navan and despite trailing - to - with just  minutes of normal time remaining, the Royal County managed to claim their first win in an Allianz league in almost two years.Eamon Wallace will certainly be on the radar of the Down defence following his decisive score at the weekend.Meath also showed they had strength in numbers with  dferent players adding to the scoreboard, five of whom came off the bench, but Down will not have the advantage of playing on home turf at Newryrsquos Paacuteirc Esler.Due to what was deemed by the GAA as a breach of their Covid- regulations, the game has been switched to the Athletic Grounds in Armagh.Ahead of Sundayrsquos clash, Down and Meath have met on  occasions in the Allianz league, with Down ahead with  wins, four more than Meath. There have also been eight draws.Downrsquos last league game against Meath was in March  and on that occasion Meath held the upper hand, running out - to - winners, with Downpatrick man Anthony Doherty scoring Downrsquos lone goal.Perhaps the most notable encounter between the two sides was back in a league game at Pairc Tailteann on February , .Down were the  All-Ireland champions and Meath were champions the previous year. For the rsquo clash, the Mourne side arrived late due to terrible weather conditions and the game was delayed by  minutes.Then, just six minutes into the game, smoke from a nearby hospital chimney fire engulfed the pitch leading to the suspension of the game for a short period.In the th minute, Down legend Paddy Doherty got his fist to a John Murphy high delivery with the ball being ruled to have crossed the goal line for the opening goal before a Meath supporter struck the umpire leaving the official unable to carry on.Although it is unlikely that there will be the same level of drama this weekend, Down and Meath know that they have to win which tees it up for a fascinating encounter.Sundayrsquos game starts at .pm..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 23%2C 2001
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash An elderly pensioner led a patientsrsquo revolt at the Downe Hospital last week after staff attempted to close a medical ward.The  year-old refused to budge and was joined in his protest against hospital administrators by two other patients who prevented porters from moving their beds to another part of the hospital.Mr George Carson from Loughmoney Road, Downpatrick, who has been in five dferent wards in the hospital over the past six weeks, said he took his stand because he fears the move could be part of a plan to scale down the local hospitalrsquos entire operation.The pensioner, who was joined in his protest by David Robinson, from Ballynahinch, and Newcastle man Peter Harbinson, said he firmly believes closing the ward will cause hardship for other patients and even fears someone could diethere is a shortage of beds in the Downe.Ironically, within hours of last Fridayrsquos protest, the local hospital was swamped with patients and some people had to spend the night on trolleys, while an elderly woman from the Kilcoo area was moved to the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald because there were no available beds at the Downe.The Down Lisburn Trust said it had to close the medical ward because funding provided by the Eastern Health Board to cope with winter pressures had been withdrawn.KILLYLEAGH ndash Plans to locate Irelandrsquos first owl sanctuary at Delamont Park outside Killyleagh have been thwarted following month-long delays at Down Council.The district has now almost certainly lost the prospect of the pound, owl conservation centre which would have created at least  jobs for the area.Ambitious plans to construct the sanctuary were first revealed during a presentation to Down Council last year, but after  months of intermittent negotiations the park is now destined for Armagh.News that the World of Owls team is in advanced negotiations with the Forestry Service in relation to the establishment of the centre at Gosford Park, was met with disbelief by local councillors at Mondayrsquos full council meeting, who believe the centre could have been a key tourist attraction for the area.The council has now launched an enquiry to established why World of Owls project manager and founder, Mr Mike Gibb, has changed his mind.Mr Gibb said that although councillors were full of enthusiasm for his project, nothing ever materialised.Although plans are now underway to begin construction of the sanctuary in Armagh this summer, Mr Gibb admits that Delamont had been his first choice.But he said he started to look for another option in March following a long silence with Down Council.DRUMANESS ndash Drumaness is set for a major revampimpressive plans for a pound, environmental regeneration scheme get the go-ahead.The project, which is being spearheaded by the Drumaness and District Community Association, would see the creation of a picturesque walkway, car parking, play facilities and a green area on land which was once common ground.The scheme, which borders the mill houses at Riverside, The Green and Green View, could get underway within the next  to  months. It is the first of a three-stage project which will eventually include the development of the Mill Pond and additional pathways.Unveiled last week, the scheme will result in existing accesses to the houses being closed up and a new roadway being created leading from the Crawfordstown Road.The blueprint also involves an information point and a five-mile circuit walk which would lead along the river to the lakes close to the main Ballynahinch to Downpatrick Road.KILLOUGH ndash A community centre in Killough has finally risen from the embers of a fire which caused devastation four years ago.The Killough Youth and Community Hall, which has lain empty since an overnight fire gutted the building in January , will this week be officially reopened.The Palatine Square building has undergone a pound, restoration project, funded by the Heritage Lottery Fund in conjunction with other funding bodies and local villagers.Fridayrsquos unveiling ceremony will be conducted by former Ombudsman and Killough native, Dr Maurice Hayes, who is also the author of the acclaimed memoir lsquoSweet Killough Let Go Your Anchorrsquo.Killough Youth and Community Hall management committee chairman, Mr Jim Conlon, said the facility would provide a focus for the entire community.ldquoThe fire in the youth club was a real set back for the people of Killough and particularly for the children, but the new refurbished hall will now provide the village with a single building that can be utilised by the entire community, he said.BALLYHORNAN ndash SDLP MP Eddie McGrady this week stressed the need for the refurbishment of Ballyhornan and Bishopscourt.The necessity of proper sewer disposal facilities in the area was emphasised to Regional Development Minister Gregory Campbell by Mr McGrady in the Assembly on Monday.Mr McGrady told the minister that existing sewers are inadequate, the mains water system is substandard and that the existing roads infrastructure needs to be urgently upgraded and improved.He said there was now an urgent need for Roads Service and Water Executive to provide a proper sewage and water treatment service along with proper road structure and footpaths.SAINTFIELD ndash A councillor has this week called for planning officials to ensure a Saintfield primary school has enough room to expand to meet future demand.Mr Robert Burgess says there is increasing concern among teachers and parents that plans to build  new homes at the rear of the Academy Primary School could prevent its future expansion.He said that in addition to restricting the growth of the Listooder Road school, the planned new homes would result in a major increase in traffic in the area which would impact on the safety of young children.Mr Burgess said the safety of the pupils is the schoolrsquos number one concern and confirmed its officials have been in contact with local planners over the past number of months.He said the safety of pupils is already jeopardised as they travel to and from school because of the traffic congestion the area.Mr Burgess said that rather than allowing the planned new homes to be built, planners should be focusing their attention on increasing parking provision for residents and parents in the vicinity of the school.He also stated that he is not opposing to new homes being built in the Saintfield area, but made it clear any new development can only proceedthe proper infrastructure is in place.NEWCASTLE ndash Newcastlersquos persistent traffic problems could soon be alleviated thanks to the appointment of the townrsquos first full-time traffic warden.From Monday, June , Mr James Woodside will be patrolling the resortrsquos streets in a bid to monitor the traffic flow and reduce the townrsquos familiar problems of double paring and bottlenecks.His appointment has come as a response to concerns expressed from residents and traders, who said they wanted the congestion in the town to be improved.Although Newcastle has been patrolled by wardens over the years, especially over the summer months, this is the first time a warden has been appointed to specically manage the townrsquos traffic and parking situation.It is also anticipated that a second warden could come into the town in the summer, but this will be accessed closer to the time.Inspector Steven Reid has said the decision to base a traffic warden at the Newcastle station came about as ldquoa response to recently expressed concerns from members of the public and businessmen and women..prettyPhoto

title: Gerry talks of famous interviews and mistaken identity
story: THE Downpatrick broadcaster ndash who has interviewed celebrities such as US singer-songwriter Garth Brooks ndash has been sharing his own story on St Patrickrsquos Podcast.Award-winning television presenter Gerry Kelly, who now lives in Ardglass, spoke to the Saint Patrick Centre pilgrim guides Martina Purdy and Elaine Kelly about le in lockdown, the art of a good interview and the night in  when Gerry Adams, then president of Sinn Fein, told him the war was over.ldquoIt was remarkable, said Kelly. ldquoWe werenrsquot expecting it to tell you the truth.Kelly recalled that he could not believe his ears when he told Mr Adams that it would helphe said the war is over. ldquoAnd he said lsquothe war is overrsquo and I was getting the wind up signalhellipit took a second or two to register.As one of Irelandrsquos most successful broadcasters Kelly has interviewed many famous people, including Roger Moore, the James Bond star. His show ran from  to .He recounted that American comedian Joan Rivers was very charming, but that it was dficult to converse with her as she had so much botox that it was hard to tellshe was laughing or crying.His favourite celebrity interview was George Best and the night he interviewed the legendary Belfast footballer, the Kelly show registered around , viewers.His anecdotes include the time a policeman rang him about an incident at Stormont only to learn he had mistaken him for MLA Gerry Kelly from Sinn Fein.Mr Kelly also spoke of his childhood and his connection to Irelandrsquos patron saint.ldquoSt Patrick is very important to me, said Mr Kelly. ldquoI was at St Patrickrsquos Primary School, St Patrickrsquos High School, I taught at St Patrickrsquos Primary School and I was in St Patrickrsquos Choral Society.Askedhe would like to walk St Patrickrsquos Way he said he had spent lockdown walking and joked that was ldquofed up walking and would prefer to take a bus.He spoke of his faith in God and joked that it was a ldquosin to close the golf courses during lockdown.ldquoWhy they closed golf is beyond me, mused Kelly. ldquoWhat is more safe than playing golf four guys on a  acre site in the open air Saint Patrickrsquos Podcast with Gerry Kelly is available from May  on the Saint Patrick Centre website. The podcast series is to celebrate the th anniversary of The Saint Patrick Centre and guests so far have also included broadcaster and presenter Eamonn Holmes, former Taoiseach Bertie Ahern, cellist Patrick Dexter and columnist Mary Kenny..prettyPhoto

title: Group forum to support Downe
story: SENIOR health officials have been asked to establish a new group to provide the community and health workers with an opportunity to help design future services at the Downe Hospital.The suggestion was put to the South Eastern Trust last week by members of a Sinn Fein delegation which included South Down MP Chris Hazzard and councillors Oonagh Hanlon and Carthy Mason.Hospital administrators were asked to establish what is being described as a ldquocommunity partnership forum in order to provide local people and health workers with a  to engage and co-design future service delivery at the Downe.The focus during last weekrsquos meeting was on the restoration of key services mdash including accident and emergency mdash which was closed over a year ago as part of the health trustrsquos planning response to Covid-.Mr Hazzard said that at the outset of the pandemic, the community understood the unprecedented nature of the unfolding health crisis and supported the reorganisation of local health services to help those who would unfortunately be in need of intensive emergency medical support.As a result, he said the Downe was ldquosoon unrecognisable as a number of key services were closed, including AE, the day procedures unit and outpatients department.The MP continued: ldquoWhere required, all available staff and equipment from these units was requisitioned for use in other parts of the health trust area.ldquoGiven the hugely disruptive impact of these changes, it was positive to hear from senior health officials that the majority of services delivered at the Downe are beginning toto pre-pandemic levels.ldquoBut it is clear that many challenges remain in order to fully restore the Downe Hospital to the status expected by the local community. This is especially true of local access to emergency care.Mr Hazzard said many were acutely aware that the Department of Health will soon launch a review of urgent and emergency care, suggesting that given the soundings to date from both health minister Robin Swann and the South Eastern Trust, there will be concern across the community that this will have ldquomajor ramications for the delivery of emergency medicine in small rural hospitals like the Downe.ldquoWith this in mind, it is vital that our local community and health workers are afforded an opportunity to be proactively involved in determining the most appropriate model of healthcare at the Downe, the MP declared.ldquoI was encouraged to hear the health trust recognise that communication and dialogue need to improve in the time ahead and that elected representatives, trade unions and community health activists can play a constructive role in partnership with officials in delivering for the Downe.Mr Hazzard said this would not only enable the local community to benefit from regular public engagement and consultation but, perhaps most importantly, would ensure a real andmeaningful process of co-design with staff and their trade union representatives.He added: ldquoI look forward to hearing back from the South Eastern Trust in the weeks ahead as to how this partnership forum can be established and will once again endeavour to work in partnership with all local political parties, staff representatives, and the Down Community Health Committee.News of the proposal for the establishment of the new health forum involving the public and health workers comes after Newry, Mourne and Down Council agreed to involve local health campaigners in a a major new offensive to ensure that the Downpatrick hospital continues to deliver key services.In April, politicians paved the way for the Down Community Heath Committee to join them in key discussions about the future of the Downpatrick hospital which they say has a critical role to play in delivering key services for people across the South Eastern Trust area in a post-Covid world..prettyPhoto

title: Hurlers rally to win over Carlow
story: DOWN hurlers showed they still have plenty to fight for after they secured a rallying comeback win inspired by their talisman Paul Sheehan against Carlow.Following last weekendrsquos defeat to Kerry, Ronan Sheehanrsquos men knew they had to put on a show at Ballycran in order to avoid an early indication of relegation.The contest was worthy of a crowd, as the action-packed affair exploded from the first whistle when Carlowrsquos Kevin McDonald put his side a goal up within the opening minute.The away side piled on relentless pressure to inflict further damage on the Down side as the points gap began to widen.However, as per the usual story, star man Sheehan began picking up the pieces and alongside Caolan Taggart and Daithi Sands, Down began to let Carlow know they werenrsquot here to just fill up the numbers.The away team lost their goal advantage on the half-hour mark when the ever dangerous Conor Woods cracked home a thumping penalty to tie the scores.Sheehan ensured Down entered the half-time break on top, scoring three points in two minutes to help his side lead - to to -.The tide really began to turn in the second-half, as Carlowrsquos James Doyle received a straight red card just three minutes into the resumption of play.Down continued to press but could not stop Carlow replying to their scores, with what turned into a back-and-forth affair before the final water-break.After the away side gained a one point lead, super Sheehan once more grabbed the game by itrsquos scruff and found the net to give Down a - to - lead.Woods doubled his goal tally soon after and despite a late surge from Carlow, the hosts held out for a - to - victory in what could prove to be vital in keeping them in the ision for another year.The win should give Down confidence ahead of this Sundayrsquos clash against Wicklow.Down scorers: P Sheehan , C Woods , C Egan , P Og McCrickard , D Hughes , D Sands , C Taggart, O MacManus, L Savage .Carlow scorers: M Kavanagh , J Nolan , C Nolan , J Kavanagh .Down -Carlow -NHL DIVISION A.prettyPhoto

title: Mailey family in True North show
story: A CARRYDUFF family will feature on the BBC One Northern Ireland documentary series, True North, next Monday night.Local teacher Tricia Mailey and her husband Sean show their everyday le with their three children as they juggle work and schoolmdash but with a dference.Tricia and her eldest two children, Cara and Noah, were born with the height-restricting condition achonlasia, also known as dwarfism.True North: Keeping Up With The Maileys follows this busy family of five across a six-month period.From seaside trips to Christmas preparations, the show reveals what le is like for a little person in a world better suited to average-height people.Despite their physical dferences, Tricia and husband Sean encourage their children to be who they want to be, although this can be challenging.The youngest family member, one-year-old Bethany, does not have achondroplasia and is almost the same height as her five-year-old brother Noah.As a child Tricia wanted to be taller and at  years old had surgery to en her legs. She is well used to people staring at her but worries about the impact this will have on Cara and Noah as they grow up.Like her mum, Cara is proud to be a little person, but being both mixed-race and small means she already gets a lot of unwanted attention.Cara has appeared on national television due to her engaging personality and is already on the path of becoming a spokesperson for smaller people.The programme looks at how Noah has just started primary school and while aware he is smaller than his classmates, he doesnrsquot fully understand his condition.The programme also looks at how for Triciarsquos mum, Libby, finding out her newborn baby had achondroplasia came as a big shock and the cruel words of doctors at the time left her fearful for her daughterrsquos future.Tricia though, has not let achondroplasia limit her ambitions and as a teacher in Cedar Integrated Primary School in Crossgar encourages her pupils to accept we are all dferent and that being small does not define who a person is.True North: Keeping Up With The Maileys, produced by Tyrone Productions and narrated by Derry Girls star, Tara Lynne OrsquoNeill, is on BBC One Northern Ireland on Monday at .pm and is also available on BBC iPlayer..prettyPhoto

title: McCauley grabs three wickets
story: SAINTFIELD defeated Dundrum by seven wickets in their recent U- friendly.Dundrum had a very young side with six U- players making their debuts and in fairness there was lots of understandable nerves present.However, all  members of the squad got chance to experience the team environment and tried admirably.The very decent all-rounder Alex Carville took four wickets from just four runs and bowled sharply, while also scoring  runs.Matthew Douglas showed he has a big future and a very solid defence as he faced the aggressive Carville and saw him off. Matthew showed how he could mix his defence and grind out his sidersquos top score of  runs.The young Dundrum side struggled with the Saintsrsquo decent bowling attack, but Ollie Robinson also showed he can stay at the crease and his patience was the key to getting his highest score of  not out and hilting some lovely shots.Dundrumrsquos captain, Noah Spence, batted too low down the order, but scored seven as James McCauley batted two not out.Saintfield looked the physically bigger U- team and were never in any trouble batting, with Matthew Scott playing wellas he retired hitting four cracking boundaries and a six.Dundrumrsquos bowlers tried hard with James Wright, who was the pick, with one for  from four overs in a very tidy spell.He will be doing a few more practice sessions with assistant coach Daniel Kearsley as there is a lot more to come from this tall fast bowler.Andrew Campbell received the man of the match accolade and took the wicket of Carville, out bowled for , which included three boundaries and a nice six.Dundrum U- coach Jeff Maguire was happy with the fielding, especially with debutants Jamie Tweedie and James McCauley.He did admit that the team needed to work harder on line and , as well as running between wickets, but the coaches will spend extra time on practice nights to improve all aspects.There were further debuts for Joscelyn Wright and Amy Spiers, with a notable mention to Ben Spiers, who performed well as wicketkeeper.The Meadow was in superb condition thanks to the grounds staff and there was a good crowd present..prettyPhoto

title: Mickey Harte delighted to walk in the steps of Saint Patrick
story: LEGENDARY Gaelic football manager Mickey Harte is to walk St Patrickrsquos Way to officially launch the pilgrim season.The Tyrone man, who led his county to three All-Ireland senior titles and now manages Louth, said he is looking forward to conquering the walk.The walk mdash which can be booked via the St Patrick Centre Downpatrick mdash includes guides Martina Purdy and Elaine Kelly and will take place on Wednesday, June .ldquoI was delighted to be invited by the Saint Patrick Centre, said Mr Harte, ldquoand we had all hoped this would happen on St Patrickrsquos Day but this was delayed due to lockdown. I have been hearing about the pilgrim walk and it sounds amazing.ldquoAs a man of faith, I am delighted to walk with other pilgrims in the steps of Irelandrsquos patron saint in the beauty of the countryside.Mr Harte, is from Ballymacilroy, outside Ballygawley, and is the longest serving manager in Tyronersquos history.He will journey the six mile route from the St Patrickrsquos Centre to Inch Abbey and then on to Saul Church, the site of St Patrickrsquos first church in Ireland. He will then joinpilgrims for lunch at Paddyrsquos Barn in Saul.After lunch he will walk a further mile or so to Slieve Patrick, site of the largest monument to St Patrick in the world. And along the way the father-of-four will visit St Patrickrsquos Roman Catholic Church, Saul, where there is part of an altar which was used by St Patrick to say mass.Dr Tim Campbell said it was great to have Mr Harte supporting the pilgrim walk, which has proved very popular.ldquoWe think St Patrickrsquos Way has captured the imagination of many and is a wonderful way to connect with other people, to connect with nature and with the spiritualty of St Patrick, he remarked.ldquoThis is a powerful heritage walk which appeals on so many levels and we hope that other people will book to join Mickey Harte on the walk.Pilgrim guide Martina Purdy said she looked forward to the start of the season. ldquoHaving Mickey Harte along on the walk is a bonus. His Catholic faith is inspirational.Pilgrim guide Elaine Kelly, who will guide the walk to Slieve Patrick in the afternoon, said Mr Harte will see the best of Co Down.ldquoMickey will have the walk of his le mdash and we hope go home energised by the spirit of St Patrick.To book guided walks contact the St Patrick Centre on   ..prettyPhoto

title: Review of Newcastle toilet facilities plan
story: A MAJOR overhaul of public toilet provision in Newcastle is being considered by Newry, Mourne and Down Council.The local authority is considering the closure of existing facilities at Central Promenade, the Islands Park and South Promenade and redeveloping an existing toilet block at Castle Park in the centre of the resort.Existing public toilets at the popular Downs Road and Donard Park areas in the town would remain open, but refurbished and upgraded.The proposal is one of the core elements of a major new public toilet strategy the local authority is spearheading which includes a controversial suggestion of charging people use some facilities in a bid to reduce vandalism and anti-social behaviour.In addition, the local authority is also reviewing public toilet opening times across the district as part of plans to invest heavily to allow people to spend a penny. There will also be increased emphasis on ensuring that public toilets meet the needs of those with autism, dementia and other health conditions.The new toilet strategy mdash which includes a review of how council-owned toilets are managed, cleaned and maintained mdash is expected to be formally signed off at tonightrsquos meeting of the local authorityrsquos Neighbourhood Services Committee.Across the district, the local authority is responsible for  public conveniences, many of which have been in place for over  years and are showing signs of corrosion and internal wear and tear. A number have also been vandalised.Councillors will be told tonight that a decision is required to repair, replace or remove these particular units and they will be provided with a detailed breakdown of the work that is required.Toilets at Castlewellanrsquos Upper Square need to be replaced while the outer shell of the building would remain in place, while the existing facility at Market Street in Downpatrick would be entirely replaced.The new strategy suggests that the current public toilets at The Rocks in Ballyhornan would be replaced as would existing toilets at the local authority-owned car park at the Newcastle Road outside Dundrum.Plans have also been drawn up to replace toilets at Crossgarrsquos Lislea Drive and at Ardglass harbour, while public toilets at the New Line in Saintfield mdash which have been repeatedly targeted by vandals mdash would replaced, alongside those at the Quoile Road in Downpatrick.Public toilets the Lough Inch cemetery in Ballynahinch and Struell Cemetery in Downpatrick are also in line for refurbishment under the new council strategy, alongside conveniences at Windmill Street in Ballynahinch.It will also be confirmed at tonightrsquos council meeting that almost  people responded to a -week consultation on the new strategy with over  percent of those who responded agreeing with the suggestion to pay to spend a penny. Concern was also expressed about the cleanliness of some public toilets and their layout.And while council toilets in Newcastle, Dundrum, Castlewellan, Downpatrick, Ballyhornan and Ardglass have reopened after being closed due to coronavirus, those in Saintfield, Ballynahinch, Crossgar and Killyleagh remain closed. They are due to reopen shortly.Cllr Billy Walker has welcomed the decision to reopen council toilets across the Rowallane area and said the fact that these particular public conveniences have been closed or over a year was ldquounacceptable.He said steps should have been taken earlier to ensure that staff were available to open and maintain the ious facilities.Cllr Walker was particularly critical of the decision to keep toilets in Killyleagh closed given the number of people who visited the town over recent months as Covid restrictions eased.ldquoPublic toilets across the Rowallane area were closed too long for my liking and I am aware that there was concern that conveniences at the townrsquos Market House and nearby community centre were also closed, he continued.ldquoI have been informed that all public toilets across the district will be reopened by June and that is welcome news. With the further easing of lockdown restrictions there will be an increase in the number of visitors to the area and it is vital that all conveniences are available..prettyPhoto

title: Success for young stars in virtual competition
story: PUPILS from Mourne Stars Speech and Drama in Newcastle have been celebrating success once again.Many pupils from Clare Murninrsquos classes took part in Newry Feis this year as they usually would have done previous years.This year was a little dferent. With the recent lockdown they didnrsquot get to stand on the stage at Newry Town Hall. Instead it was a virtual competition where pupils sent in video recordings of their poetry recitals.All of the pupils used excellent vocal skills showing wonderful confidence in all age categories.ldquoThe Newry Feis is a wonderful opportunity for the pupils of speech and drama to show off everything they learn in class, for example, proper use of tone, pause, pace, pitch, projection, volume and articulation skills, Clare explained.She said she was proud of every one of her pupils who entered the competitions and thanks all of the parents for their unwavering support.She also said she was delighted to see so many of the pupils be awarded within their age categories, which she described as an excellent tribute to the hard work they all put in.If you are interested in your son or daughter taking part in speech and drama contact Clare via email mournestars@gmail or follow Mourne Stars Speech and Drama on Facebook and Instagram..prettyPhoto

title: Tally’s men lose out to Mayo stars in opener
story: DOWN senior footballers did not have their fairytale start back in Division  after being comprehensively beaten by a strong Mayo side.It was always going to be an uphill battle for Paddy Tallyrsquos team as they faced off against a recently demoted Mayo outfit in Castlebar.Despite last yearrsquos relegation, Mayo began their campaign with strong intent and although the Mourne county could not be faulted for lack of heart, it was soon clear it was the home sidersquos game to lose.Down started admirably, matching Mayo for the first  minutes as the sides scored four points a piece.However, it wouldnrsquot be long before Tommy Conroy would open the goal scoring as he rapidly burst through the Down defence to place the ball under goalkeeper Rory Burns.Down showed they would not go without a fight and chalked up a couple more points to bring the scores - to - at the half-time interval.The game was perhaps put completely beyond the red and black outfitrsquos reach when Mayo fired home another goal on the  minute-mark.A consolation goal from Down substitute Stephen McConville allowed for a more modest scoreline but evidently, it was clear that this Mayo side will no doubt be pushing for ato the top tier.Down manager Paddy Tally reflected on his teamrsquos performance after the full-time whistle.ldquoI felt, at times, we just didnrsquot get to the intensity of the game, he said. ldquoTo be honest, it was always going to be a wee bit of fun coming here today to see where the boys are at.Itrsquos a bit freaky, a team like Mayo being in Division Two. Naturally there would be a bit of a gap in experience and quality.Mayo manager James Horan was delighted with his teamrsquos effort as he looks ahead to a promising campaign.ldquoSix or seven sessions is all wersquove had so we were very unsure because we just didnrsquot know where we would be, he said.ldquoThe guys, you could see there, did a huge amount of work inidually over the winter. They were in very good shape and quickly got up to speed, he continued.ldquoWe got sloppy towards the end but overall we were very happy with today.Down now look ahead to the weekend when they face off against Meath following their win over Westmeath.Mayo: R Hennelly E Hession, O Mullin , L Keegan M Plunkett , P Durcan, R Brickenden M Ruane , D OrsquoConnorF McDonagh , K McLoughlin, J FlynnT Conroy , C OrsquoConnor , R OrsquoDonoghue .Subs used: E McLaughlinfor Brickenden, B Walsh for FlynnC Loftus for McDonaghS Coen for McLoughlin, A Orme for OrsquoDonoghue , J McCormack for D OrsquoConnor , C Boyle for Keegan .Down: R Burns G Collins, G McGovern, P Murdock K McKernan, P Laverty, J Flynn R McEvoy, C Mooney J Guinness , C Poland, C Doherty D Guinness , C Quinn , B OrsquoHagan .Subs used: L Kerrfor DohertyO McCabe for PolandD OrsquoHagan for McKernanP Devlinfor McKernan, L Middleton for Quinn, S McConvillefor McEvoyB McArdle for Murdock Mayo -Down -NFL DIVISION .prettyPhoto

title: To hear Hugh was a ‘peacemaker’ was very touching
story: GERALDINE McGrattan was  and away on a holiday in Tralee when she first heard that her beloved uncle, Fr Hugh Mullan, had been shot dead in Ballymurphy in Belfast on August , .The tragic news was confirmed to her grandparents, John and Mary Mullan, around am the following day.Her mother Teresa, Hughrsquos eldest sister, was pregnant at the time and Geraldine could not wait to get home to Portaferry.ldquoGranny was distraught, I arrived home late on the Tuesday evening as it took so long and to get through the Newry border checkpoint, she recalled.ldquoIt was so unbelievable, I picked up a paper in Dublin to read what had happened. My uncle was the first to be shot, then Frank Quinn, the  year-old, who was shot beside him and killed.What hurt Geraldine and the wider Mullan family so much was in press reports Fr Mullan was said to have been involved in a gun battle with soldiers.ldquoHe was such a big part of our family le, for the lies that were told about him were very dficult for us all, she said. ldquoIt was hard enough to lose him, but to lose him like that and then everything afterward was so hard.She said on that fateful day, her uncle had been trying all day to calm things down.ldquoThere was trouble from Loyalists behind Springfield Park and the people in Springfield Park started to evacuate their houses and tried to flee across a piece of waste ground over to Moyard to safety.ldquoBricks and stones were being thrown at their houses and houses were badly damaged. They were carrying children across the waste ground and firing started. A man, Bobby Clarke, was shot and wounded in a field and local people called for a priest as they thought he was going to die.ldquoUncle Hugh had been standing outside his own house and had spent the day ringing the Army, trying to get thing quietened and calmed. He called the Army to tell them that he was going out to the wasteland to help an injured man. Then he got a white cloth, began to wave it and went out onto the wasteland.ldquoHe got to Bobby and he told Uncle Hugh he wasnrsquot too bad. Uncle Hugh said he would go and get him an ambulance but would give him the Anointing of the Sick to help him anyway.ldquoHe did that and he was making his way back to get an ambulance when he was shot. He was shot at least twice and left in the field. Frank Quinn went out to help Uncle Hugh and he was shot and died instantly.The family never received any official explanation about Fr Mullanrsquos death.ldquoIn the early days, we were told that Uncle Hugh had been killed in crossfire during a gun battle, said Mrs McGrattan. ldquoNewspapers reported that he was a gunman, carrying a weapon. No one ever contacted us, there was never a person at the door to tell us what had happened.Along with the joy from last Tuesday of the coronerrsquos ruling that Fr Mullan was an innocent, Mrs McGrattan said there was also a lot of sadness for her.ldquoIt was a sad day as my grandparents, John and Mary, werenrsquot there to hear it, nor were my parents, Teresa and Gerry, my husband Gerard and my brother Hugh Kearney. So many of us have died in those  years and didnrsquot get to hear the good words she used.There was another loss for her family mdash her mother Teresarsquos baby died at birth and her parents moved to England shortly afterwards.Mrs McGrattan said she was really moved to hear the testimonies of civilian witnesses who gave evidence during the inquest.ldquoWhenever Mrs Justice Keegan said that Hughrsquos story was stark and in her opinion, he was a peacemaker, and totally innocent, it lted a weight off me.ldquoIrsquove known for the past  years that Hugh was innocent but now the world knows. To hear him call him a peacemaker was very touching. It was though that I had been coiled up in a tight spring and suddenly just released. It was a great day.She praised and thanked the Portaferry community for their support over the years.ldquoThe people of Portaferry were so generous and so kind to the whole family at that time, actually all through the years. The community held Uncle Hugh in great respect and always have done..prettyPhoto

title: pentecost bishops clogher give joint message
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityBishop Ian Ellis, the Church of Ireland Bishop of Clogher and Bishop Larry Duffy, Roman Catholic Bishop of Clogher, have come together to give a joint message to mark the feast of Pentecost, highlighting the importance of "speaking together about the goodness of God across barriers".Pentecost Sunday marks the end of the -day season of Easter and the descent of the Holy Spirit in the upper room and the beginning of apostolic preaching, thus marking a defining moment in the origin of the Christian Church. It is celebrated on Sunday, May .In their joint message, the bishops opened by quoting a verse from the book of Acts in the Bible: "All of them were filled with the Holy Spirit and began to speak in other languages, as the Spirit gave them ability - Acts :."They continued: "One of the great marks of the first Pentecost was the ability the Holy Spirit gave the apostles to speak across barriers of language of the works of God.ldquoThe Spirit today gives the people of God the same ability to speak as one across all kinds of barriers and boundaries.ldquoWe rejoice today that we can speak together to both our church communities and beyond with a common message of hope through the resurrection of Jesus Christ."Stating their disappointment that for a second year they are unable to mark this "great feast" by coming together for their Ecumenical Service of Prayer, as they have done for almost  years, the bishops added: "This service allows us to give thanks and praise together to God the Father, Son and Holy Spirit. Please God, next year this might again be possible."They continued their message by noting how speaking together about "the goodness of God" across barriers is an "important expression of the language of hope".They said: "This is so important as we begin the journey of recovery from the impact of coronavirus. There has been much suffering the loss of loved ones, illness, financial challenge and isolation.ldquoWe all need to hear the healing and strengthening words of Christ, lsquoCome unto me all who are weary and heavy-laden, and I will give you restrsquo."Outlining how during the pandemic people quickly realised how important communication is when denied simple non-verbal qualities of close contact and touch, the bishops said: "We discovered how much we need the warmth of the love of our family and friends.ldquoThe telephone and internet became our key means of keeping in touch and we thank God for these technological aids that kept us connected.ldquoCrucially, we learned how much we are indebted to medical staff, nurses, key workers and volunteers who have communicated dedication, care and love to the community through their skill and acts of kindness."We must continue to communicate the language of love and hope across all barriers and boundaries.ldquoIt would be so easy after this long period of restrictions to move to despair and lose hope. Yet we believe there are signs of new le all around us in the vaccination programme and the good response to public health guidance.ldquoLet us encourage one another to communicate the hope that by Godrsquos help, our common le will slowly , and together seek his grace to renew our lives."In closing, the bishops said: "We pray that the Holy Spirit of Pentecost may inspire us so that we communicate in our words and deeds the hope we have in God.ldquoMay we as Christian people speak of our belief in the transforming power of God, and by his Spirit to work together for the rebuilding and re-energising of our churches and society.This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - title: arlene foster questions existence of letter at centre of dup coup
story: Sam McBride: A curious episode shows that the NI protocol is now too confusing for even the EU to understand   Devastation after NI house fire claims le of one man and leaves another ‘critically ill’ - PSNI launch investigation into cause of blaze aS officers in area carry out inquiriesNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedHome and GardenTechnologyFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsPoliticsArlene Foster questions existence of letter at centre of DUP coupOutgoing DUP leader Arlene Foster has questioned the existence of a letter at the centre of an internal party coup against her.By Rebecca BlackMonday, th May , : pm  "       "  ]]First Minister Arlene Foster at the Strand Centre Cinema in east Belfast to mark the reopening of indoor arts venues, after the latest easing of the Covid- rules in Northern IrelandThe letter reportedly signalled no confidence in Mrs Foster’s leadership and was said to have been signed by a majority of the party’s senior elected representatives.It led to Mrs Foster announcing her intention to resign as DUP leader and First Minister of Northern Ireland.Lagan Valley MLA Edwin Poots went on to win the first leadership contest in the party’s history by a narrow margin over MP Sir Jeffrey Donaldson.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...Mr Poots’ election is to be ratied by the party’s ruling council on Thursday, the day before Mrs Foster is to step down as DUP leader.She will remain in post as First Minister until the end of June.She told reporters during a visit to the Strand Arts Centre in east Belfast on Monday that she had not seen the no confidence letter, describing it as “so-called”.Mrs Foster also said she had not had the opportunity to speak to Mr Poots yet, adding she did not feel under pressure to step down as First Minister earlier than planned.“I’m not under any pressure. I haven’t had the opportunity to speak with Edwin yet but I’m sure, when I do, we’ll discuss all of those matters,” she said.“He hasn’t been speaking to me as yet and actually I still have yet to see the letter, so-called, and I’m beginning to wonder is there a letter at all, but in any event I look forward to seeing the letter and I look forward to having that conversation whenever Edwin reaches out.Mrs Foster said the letter “was supposed to be signed by  of my colleagues”.“Some of my colleagues are indicating they were told they were number , even though a number of them had been told that, so I would quite like to see the letter just from my own point of view to see what’s in it, and to see what was told to my colleagues,” she said.“It’s now been nearly four weeks since I heard about it and I still haven’t seen it.”Frontbench DUP MLA and Stormont Economy Minister Diane Dodds earlier said she hoped the party could heal itself following the leadership election.Mr Poots has said he plans to hold one-on-one meetings with MLAs and will later announce his ministerial team – including who will be first minister, having ruled himself out, saying he would prefer to concentrate on leading the DUP.Asked whether she had had her meeting with Mr Poots, Mrs Dodds said she had spoken to him.“I obviously have spoken to Edwin, that is critical for the way forward for the party,” she told media as she visited the Grand Central Hotel in Belfast.“I hope that the party can heal itself and to move forward, because the most important thing that the party can do from now on is to ensure that we attract the greatest and widest proportion of those people who are pro-union voters, those people who are concerned about the economy and who know that we have the policies, and the drive and the energy to make Northern Ireland a great place to live, to work and to do business.”Earlier, Mrs Dodds told the BBC there was a “huge job of work to do” for Mr Poots.Asked whether she felt he was the person to do the job, she responded: “The party takes a democratic decision and therefore that is the decision, and that is the position that we have arrived at.“I have made it very clear that the way forward for the party, and indeed the way forward for unionism in general, is to be as inclusive as it can possibly be to ensure that we are attracting pro-union voters to the cause of the DUP but generally to the cause of the union, and we will do that by being inclusive and being open-minded on the values and the importance of the union to Northern Ireland.”Asked whether she thought she would still be Stormont Economy Minister next Thursday, Mrs Dodds said: “I am not going to allow any of that to spoil my breakfast this morning in such a wonderful setting as the Grand Central Hotel, as for now, I am continuing to do my job as the Economy Minister.”  "       "  Get the latest news on the CoronavirusWe have launched a daily public interest bulletin to deliver all the updates and vital
